description:
House of Shields is a pretty cool old establishment in Downtown SF.  Very sturdy old architecture and it's dark and gloomy and miserable like the rest of San Francisco.

For a Saturday night, I played tourist to the city I grew up in.  A couple of friends and myself walk about SF bar hopping.  As a tourist, bar hopping in San Francisco is quite fun.  I hate the city because parking, traffic and the people suck.  But on weekends, if you do not have to worry about driving, walking about downtown, chinatown, North Beach and even Aquatic Park can be fun.  We started by watching a 1pm Giants vs Dodgers Game, then, checked into our hotel on the South of Market, went to at least 7 or 8 bars and finished here where we mellowed out with a perfect gin and tonic.

The darkness inside here is true San Francisco.  Bar hop and make this your last check in.  It's like walking into a morgue.
author: Tony U.

description:
After decades of being a bar that generally attracted bike messengers between pickups around SOMA, it's nice to see that House Of Shields is still plugging right along. These days, the clientele is made up primarily of people working in the area's various startups, but it still has that old school charm, slightly musty scent, and $3 Modelos in a can that's sure to delight bar goers of any background.

It can get packed during happy hour, so choose your time for a tipple wisely.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Had such a good fun time at this bar! Went straight after work and it wasn't too busy at all. We were able to grab a drink and find a spot to sit easily. The bartenders were extremely friendly and knew how to whip up a quick drink. I really can't believe I hadn't visited this place sooner. Lore has it this place was open during prohibition and patrons in the hotel across the street would take secret tunnels to walk under and into the bar unnoticed. True or not it added another point of intrigue to this old timey bar with great music, chill crowds and good drinks. I'll be back soon enough!
author: Liz B.

description:
Came here for a drink with some co-workers after work on a week day. I was not impressed. 

Perhaps it may have something to do with the holiday party that was taking place upstairs but it seemed understaffed and overpacked. Tons of people crammed in front of the bar while staff tried to finagle through the sea of people while breaking glasses and pushing patrons to the side.  

There was hardly any place to stand but we lucked out and took a table from a few people who were leaving shortly after we arrived. 

I ordered their pimm's cup and it was well made. My complaint is how long it took to make since there was only one bartender and about thirty people trying to order drinks/waiting for their order at the bar. There should've been at least two people downstairs. 

With all variables considered I wouldn't recommend this place if this is how it is during a peak time in SF. 

Not a atmosphere that's very relaxing after a long day of work. 

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back to this place.
author: Ashley L.

description:
Pappy Van Winkle (reserve).. I can almost stop there! This place has some serious ambiance, great bourbons and really cool bartenders. The motif will make you feel like you've stepped back into the 30's with its beautiful dark wood bar and dimly light seating areas. 
Huge selection of top-shelf alcohols and a great location.
author: Brian O.

description: I had the basil gimlet. Drinks are good for the price... but I'd pay more for better service.
author: Rachel N.

description: Old school since 1908. I couldn't pass up a historic bar like this one that was across the street from my hotel The Palace. I went on a Tuesday night and it was slow with only a few patrons. The place screams yesteryear with its amazing original interior. They offer beer on tap which is a big plus for me.
author: Franklin M.

description:
I love this place for the bartenders and how delicious they make a sazerac.  It is also located really close to bart which is nice.

The people who frequent this place usually tend to give off a pretty rude vibe.  It just always feels a little awkward in here especially when there isn't much seating.
author: Amanda K.

description:
HOS is a SOMA classic. Been around for a long, long time and they sure know how to pour a drink. I've been here for many-a work events, discussions with clients over drinks, and just with friends after work for Happy Hour. The bartenders are nice, the drinks are strong, and the space is classy...but the crowd is always a blast. Nothing is uptight here, just come and enjoy.

If you can snag a seat at the bar I'd say go for it, but expect a crowd and the booths go fast too. It's narrow between the bar and the booths, but squeeze your way to the back for a little more open space. Wait your turn for drinks, they will come and I've never seen the folks here not hustle. Upstairs is a nice private event area and I've attended a few up there. It's a tad dark and musky, that's the vibe of this high class dive. Their pour a great pint of guinness, the moscow mules are good, the old fashioned is solid and a personal favorite of mine is a Negroni with Hendricks. These guys do it right with a twist of orange rind.  Their signature cocktails are good too, I can't recall any names as I'm more of an old-fashioned or negroni guy, but every one I've had here I've liked. 

Also, please stop complaining about it being packed. They cannot magically double in size, they have no control over the serious lack of good bars in SOMA and let's not confuse that with consistently good drinks and service. My advice, if you can get off a tad early, hit them at 430-5pm and you'll be fine, if not, suck is up or go somewhere else.
author: Nate E.

description:
It's kind of rough finding a spot to drink after work in FiDi. It's pricey, there are surprisingly few options, and you're competing for space like it's the last lifeboat on the Titanic. House of Shields is the most acceptable place on 2nd and New Montgomery. It's an old-school cocktail bar in a space that's been in use for something like 110 years (and it looks it, in a good way). 

Cool, high ceilings. Lots of mirrors. Neon sign. A small lounge space upstairs. A weird giant urinal. You know. The works. 

Prices are not absurd. It gets a little packed at peak times, but not SUPER packed. There's plenty of seating. I'd complain that it gets hard to hear other people talk when it's super busy, but... C'mon. It's the Financial District. It's going to get jammed with people at 6pm and they're going to have conversations and it's gonna get noisy. 

The Smoke Stack is a pretty good cocktail. I haven't tried any of the others, but everyone I know who has ordered one has been more-or-less satisfied. They've got a pretty deep list of spirits. All the bartenders are relaxed and on-the-ball. And sharply dressed.

tl;dr if you're looking for a drink and everywhere is a nightmare, try House of Shields. (or Wine Down.)
author: Jim M.

description:
Oh my God.
The smell of pee is so terrible in this place I can't believe I could even finish a drink. Husband went to the bathroom and the urinal was broken and toilet filled with pee so high it was to the rim of the bowl.
Gross. Gross. Gross
author: Ashleigh V.

description: Bartender has serious attitude (guy with dark hair and beard). Gave us serious condescending attitude right when we walked in felt so uncomfortable the whole time we were ordering. Had a stank attitude when ordering drinks. Asked for a water and he made a rude remark. Don't know what this guys attitude was for but saw him being friendly to some white guy, maybe hispanics aren't his cup of tea. What a shame because my friend and I are serious tippers and had a few drinks in mind. Ordered one and left. Management seriously needs to reconsider this guy.
author: Karen A.

description: Loved the vibe. Came with the wifey and people watched. The John Daly tea and acai cooler was tasty. Loved the brick and art.
author: Rob H.

description: The House of Shields is a great place for a cocktail. They are conveniently located a short walk from the Montgomery BART station. The interior of the bar harkens back to a time of Charlie Chaplin and Harry Houdini. But the drink selection is a kin to the time of Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Sammy Davis, Jr.  The drinks are stiff and well made. The bartender is knowledgable and friendly. The problem during my visit was there was only one bartender with a packed house. I visited at 4:30 on a Tuesday. So, you can tell this a popular place, and for good reason. Unfortunately, the wait for a drink was long because they were understaffed.
author: David F.

description:
I go here pretty often with coworkers since it's close to where I work. I always order the Hemingway daquiri. It tastes like a better mimosa, if that makes sense. I do think the drinks are kinda pricy for just the amount you get.

But it's a pretty cool place with lots of history. They have a lot of booths and tables downstairs and upstairs there are comfy chairs. I will say tho, that I think the music is a bit too loud. Like you will have to get real close to people's faces to hear what they're saying.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Stopped in here with some friends after the Giants game on Saturday. It is a really cool two story bar inside. There is a fair amount of seats at the bar and a few booths across from it. There is also an upstairs balcony area that looks down to the first floor bar. Cool for picture taking.

The four of us got seats at the bar and we ordered a couple of cocktails. I had a Taqueray and Tonic and an Old Fashioned. Both very good! 

This place is a couple of blocks from the Montgomery St. BART station so stop on by before you jump on or off the train!
author: William R.

description: This is a small place, but quite atmospheric.  Love the Art Nouveau touches.  Big wooden booths line the walls and there is a small bar.  We tried the Hemingway Daiquiri- which was very strong and very good.  Grapefruit dominates- but there are other flavors as well.  At 12 dollars it isn't exactly a deal, but we wanted to check this bar off our bucket list.  I'm not sure I'd go back, but I'm glad we tried it. It's easy to find- with that giant neon sign, and it's very close to Montgomery Bart.
author: Alex M.

description: Talk about a blast from the past!! I felt like I had stepped back in time the moment I walked into this amazing bar. Even more magical is that I came here on New Years Eve! Being our first stop on our Nee Years Eve walking pub crawl, my boyfriend and I decided to stroll in here because it looked like the perfect spot to enjoy an old fashioned drink. The inside is delightful! The ambient lighting and cozy booth seats make this bar not only classic but so dreamy! We enjoyed a couple of martinis here and were thrilled with the service and the care and detail that went into making our cocktails. I love that (unlike your average bars in San Francisco, or anywhere else for that matter) this bar did not have TVs plastered all over the walls. What a nice treat from those loud bars where some kind of game or tv show is always streaming! I feel like my boyfriend and I enjoyed our time together as it was intended, without distractions. What a special time here! As a matter of fact, we lost so much track of time sitting in here sharing our drinks and some laughs that I almost felt like I was in Las Vegas where there is no concept of night and day until you stroll out of those casinos and realize it's the next day! I was strangely at peace with the fact that everything was so simple yet elegant here. Not even a clock on the wall! Our time spent was so enjoyable and I know we will be back to this timeless little bar!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Okay I've been wanting to come here for a while it definitely it has its charm.   No TV's just drinks.  It was pretty packed on a Friday even though there was no real happy hour. 

The crowd is a little more mature then the surrounding bars and for me thats a big plus +2 stars just for that. 

The bartenders seemed really helpful and cool.  And we were able to find a booth seat another plus.    

The old school decor and cool dark ambiance was also very different.   I'm sure my company would love to go again its different enough to make it a unique place in SOMA for us.
author: Homer S.

description: This place is beautiful!  This bar has been continuously open since 1908!  The architecture is worth going to check out, it's stunning.  I have been there several times with friends and it has always been great.  I love that is has no television!  A must visit if you like old architecture.
author: Annelise M.

description:
Seriously, not so sure what the big deal about this place is, only reason its not getting a 2 by me is because the drinks are actually good.

The clientele is very rude.. I'm going to assume its mostly financial people.  It's basically a 80 to 20 ratio of middle aged men that look like the only reason they are out is because they don't want to go home to their wives.

Other than that, still a decent place to go, drinks are good, but way too expensive for my taste.
author: Cliff S.

description: We initially walked in here to start our night of drinking but it was pretty empty and no TVs (there was a warriors game on). So after the game, we came back and it was a little more hopping. But we were still able to snag a table in the back. They also have an upstairs area but not sure if that was open to the public at the time. I have a couple of friends who are regulars here so I let them order. I tried the Gold rush. It's bourbon, honey and lemon served in one of those old timey champagne glasses. It was delicious and strong. It's dark and the ambiance is very intimate. I only tried the one drink but I wouldn't mind coming back to try some of their other cocktails.
author: Alison W.

description: Thank you Steve! My friend and I are very happy for your service! We hope to comeback soon!
author: Kenya R.

description: I really liked this place. Mellow vibe. Attire ranged from smart dressy to casual. The establishment has been continuously in business since 1906 under the same name and even during prohibition. The art nouveau decor is really beautiful. But most important the drinks are GOOD   and fairly priced. I'm a French 75 snob. This was the best French 75 I've had, the bar tender user elderflower instead of simple syrup. Then she floated the champagne on top.  The only other French 75 that would rival this is the one at the Plaza in NYC.
author: The Entrepid M.

description:
15 minutes, that's all I need.

It took me 15 minutes to finish a beer which is a record since I usually babysit my beer

It took me 5 minutes to order and receive my drink

It took me less than 1 minute to determine if I was interested 

15 minutes was all I needed to do what I had to do and during those 15 minutes, all I could think about was when the 15 minutes was going to end.

$6 Stella, friendly staff
author: Linda N.

description:
House of Shields rivals any SoMa bar in drink quality and overall atmosphere. Between the high shelves behind the bar, the mixology skills of the bartenders and the colorful mix of business casual and just plain crazy patrons, it's hard not to have a good time here. 

Slink to the back and you'll find a second level that is usually dark and barely occupied on weekdays. I like to come up here and people-watch, although I know that sounds kind of creepy. It can get loud downstairs so this perch is better for small groups and conversations. 

A shout out as well to the bartenders. Good attitudes are contagious and on my multiple visits I've always seen smiles from these guys. Keep up the good vibes and drink-slinging and I'll keep spreading the word.
author: Alex L.

description:
Is there an upstairs or another room or is this bar just quite small? There's not really a good place to stand around and there are very few seats, so it's a bit awkward, especially carrying a purse and briefcase and whatnot after work.  

A coworker of mine suggested this place for an office happy hour destination but I cannot see this being fun to go to in a group. When I went, I was with a girlfriend and the bartender was really awkward about asking for IDs, I was unsure of whether he was asking for mine and or my friend's. He should've just asked for both of them with conviction to be polite if he was unsure of just one of us. I ordered a dirty martini and it wasn't dirty enough. It really didn't taste dirty at all. At the time, I wondered if maybe I had just been drinking unsophisticated dirty martinis, but then I realized that I've had dirty martinis at the Top of the Mark, The View, et al. and I'm quite certain that I haven't been getting poorly made martinis at EVERY spot aside from this one.  The martini was at least $12 too. 

I would go back here for a beer if somebody invited me but I wouldn't go rushing back out of choice.
author: Emma H.

description:
Came here on a rainy Friday night. We had some time to kill before our dinner reservation, so Peter L suggested House of Shields. I've never been here before, so I was down to check it out.

Walking in, HoS has a very dark, old school kind of vibe. A little dive bar mixed with old charm. Dark large booths and lots of wood. We had a group of 5 people and luckily were able to claim a large booth.

Scrolling through yelp, it seemed like the Moscow Mule was the drink to get. But Peter suggested the Gold rush: bourbon, honey, lemon ($11 each) instead. I've never actually had a Gold rush, so I figured why not try it. It was good. The citrus went nicely with the bourbon. I actually didn't care for the honey flavor since I'm not a huge fan of honey as a sweetener. But it was subtle, so it didn't totally bother me.

For a rainy night, it was fun ducking into HoS for a quick drink. Would like to try some more as the Smoke Stack and Brooklyn sounded mighty tasty!
author: Elena N.

description:
Was early for an event so we ducked into the House of Shields, have to say this is a nice looking bar, its manly feeling, rich wood work and just manly.  I learned that back in the day this was a gentleman's club, no women allowed, (it's not anymore) and it sort of gives the feeling that's is a man's bar, so felt like I was breaking some rules just being there .

After checking out the menu I knew what I wanted so I ordered up a Moscow mule, love that drink! It's just so fresh and refreshing and this one was just as great too! Loved the chill of copper cup.  House of Shields has 2 floors but I never made it to the 2nd floor to check it out. Also this bar does not have a tv nor did I see any clocks but it was a fun time for sure! 

Glad I had the chance to stop in and check out and I know if I am in the area again I will be back.
author: Monica O.

description:
I love the House of Shields. Back when I worked in that area, too many years ago to count, it was my go-to bar after work. It's a beautiful, old bar with a classic neon sign (and name). Who could resist? Actually, at that time, it was pretty simple and often quiet, except on Friday evenings. One could even say that the drinks were not very fancy - it was a place designed for people who want to get drunk, as the bartender says in "It's a Wonderful Life." I kind of wondered whether it might go out of business.

So I stopped in about a year ago, and it was much busier. It was hard to get the bartender's attention, frankly. But once I did, he made me a superb margarita - something fru-fru that I never would have ordered in the old days (stuck with straight martinis and whiskeys). I settled in at a stool and had a great drink. It has changed generations and become more modern in some ways, but it's still the House of Shields.
author: Mister K.

description:
Really slow service tonight. 

Dark with lots of old wood. Plenty of wood booths and comfortable bar. Loud 60s music. 

Bar tenders are courteous and fast and know their drinks.  Excellent classic cocktails with large, single blocks of ice. Good selection of bottled beers, including Duvel. A nice, "traditional" atmosphere. Wonderful place for a drink.

A great Old Fashion and Sazerac. 
This is what a cocktail bar should be like!

But, no Wi-Fi and they want a credit card AND an ID for a Moscow Mule because they are afraid of losing the copper mugs.
author: Chris S.

description: I want to make this status long enough to not be a tip and so people will read it but other than "this place is so awesome" I really don't have a lot of other words. Lmao. Come here, drink here, enjoy yourself because you will. :)  damn good spot with a twist of history! Who could ask for more???
author: Michelle P.

description:
I'm a fan! 

Cheap beer. 

Diverse Crowd. 

Nice selection of scotch and whiskey and the bartenders can whip up a nice martini according to my wife. 

Cool build out too with a lot of wood and ornate design features on the pillars and ceilings -- great light fixtures as well, which give it a very old timey vibe. It's dark, a bit of a dive but with a lot of character and charm. The neon sign out front reminds me of LA's "Seven Grand." 

Supposedly, there's an underground tunnel that leads to the hotel that was used by thirsty patrons during prohibition. Not sure how true this is but it makes for a cool story. 

At the end of the day, it's a great place to start or end the night!
author: Jeff S.

description: Fantastic bar in a great area of San Francisco.  There's a long wooden bar as well as booth seating on the main floor.  Very vintage and old school atmosphere. There is an upstairs area which makes for a nice private gathering if you have 15-20 ppl.  I held a happy hour event here and it was nice and private.  Drinks were very tasty, especially their Smoke Stack with the orange rind. Bartender was fast and efficient.  I ordered a glass of sparkling wine which they served in an old Hannah restaurant glass.  Prices were good for the city.
author: Laura W.

description:
Whether it's Happy Hour or a midnight capper, House of Shields tends to get the call more than most SOMA spots. It has just about everything for everyone: killer drink selection, plenty of space, friendly bartenders, and a decent crowd just about every night. What's more amazing to me is that this place has been around for more than 100 years, real talk.

Wine-os, cocktail lovers, beer enthusiasts, there is something for everyone. As a man of the cocktail, I've had more than enough moscow mules here to consider myself a semi-regular (when I'm around). Served in a chilled metal cup with with a handle, it beats holding a glass any day. I can also vouch for their old fashioned as well, which is very potent.

The rustic decor is a nice change of pace from the overly white collar neighborhood. Ambiance is never dull and the intimate vibe makes this place more about the company vibe than the usual nightlife aura. Even the bathrooms are fairly retro, but in a vintage early 1900s kind of way.

Timing is everything. If you come during a primetime hour, finding a place to sit or stand can be tough. The second level is not keen to good ventilation and the booths downstairs are really 4 person areas at best. Sometimes it's kind of nice to sit at the bar and get pulled into some good conversation while sipping your poison.

Be good to the bartenders and they'll be super awesome right back. Don't be afraid to request for a bigger pour and even though the accept credit cards, cash is always king.
author: Jando S.

description:
HOS offers a nice dimly lit bar, easily accessible to the working SOMA crowd. As most bars in the area the music volume is almost always unnecessarily louder than needs to be. 

Bartenders here have all been world class in my experience - these guys make it worth coming back.

HOS gets stars for accessibility and not doing anything wrong, but it doesnt do anything memorable hence only the 3 stars.
author: Oleg H.

description: The kind of place where you order drinks, they tell you a price, then after you give them your card they ring it for more. I would have tipped the difference.
author: Daniel E.

description:
The ONLY REASON to come to this bar is one of the bartenders has the most awesome and amazing Christopher Walken impression! I have tried to drop random quotes from his movies and he will break them out in perfect form! 

The cocktail drinks are made slowly and with care (tasty). The time taken might slow down service which is cause for concern when crowded (not usual), but worth it in the end. However the atmosphere of the other bartenders make it appear that they are only working there sarcastically. 

Again, not sure of his name, but "Christopher Walken Bartender"... You Rock, Make Awesome Drinks, are a blast to be around and make this bar worth it. Without you, this place is a depressing dark wooded gin joint with bad plumbing.
author: Jimbo J.

description:
The Moscow mule is made perfectly every time I order one for me and all my friends. 
When in the downtown area this is easily one of the best places to come. 
They could use more seats but it's not that bad if your in a bigger group than 4
author: Blake R.

description:
hahhahahaha I waited over an hour for one weak drink at a bar that basically reminded me of college, complete with sticky tables and floors.

I ordered the drink and waited patiently. After around 25 minutes, I reminded the bartender. After 25 more minutes, I told the other bartender that I was waiting on my drink. After another 15 minutes, I remind him again and he thought I was at the bar to order a second one. He basically gives up on the other bartender and makes me the drink himself. The bar was not busy.

The drink was an extremely watered down Moscow Mule that I really wish I hadn't waited so long for.

This place is terrible.
author: Brad P.

description: House of shields is a great spot to grab a few drinks after work. The only issue is space - it's a popular spot, and there aren't a lot of tables and seats. Bar space is also limited. It's great for what it is though, a dive bar. The drinks are good and not too pricey. It's conveniently located net Montgomery Bart. If you can find a spot, grab a drink and hang out here!
author: Mollie H.

description: Beautiful historic bar. High coffered ceiling. Classic neon sign. Baroque chandeliers. Carved wooden bar. Booth seating. Go on the weekend when it's not swarming with the Financial District crowd.
author: Patrick S.

description: Cool bar with a historic feel to it. Very high ceilings and amber dim lighting with leather topped bar stools lining the bar and a few wooden booths. Our bartender worked quickly and was friendly. This is also one of the few bars the fiance and I have seen have a bottle of Pappy Van Winkle among the bar collection.
author: Christina S.

description:
I met my love here. Whistle Pig. One cube. 

A historical bar where you can almost hear the whispers of secrets still lingering on the walls. This place suits my fancy just fine.
author: Kim W.

description:
I recently hosted a private reception at HOS. Eric Passetti was very communicative and returned emails promptly. I knew the cocktails would be delicious but what was a pleasant surprise was the food--I requested all-vegetarian appetizers and Eric put together a great (and plentiful) menu. 

The upstairs loft was a great setup and location for the event. I only wish I had thought to reserve an extra hour because our guests were having such a good time.

When we have another event, we will think of HOS.
author: Annabelle I.

description:
A bit pricey...but you get what you pay for. The drinks are amazing.  
I think my gf and I may have upset the bartender after sharing our diet tips until closing lol
author: Allen P.

description:
We three not-so-wise men came here on our pub crawl educational retreat and were wowed big time. Everything about this place is classic SF and the mixologist, Ethan, who took very good care of us, is a fountain of knowledge. This is a very friendly bar with an upbeat,  classic decor and feel with a great location.

Ethan was most amenable to mixing a Scotch Bonnet to my recipe and poured a Martinez and Sazerak for my co-conspirators, all to perfection. He shared ghost stories of the establishment and gave us tasting lessons for a few unique amaros as well as where to get them locally. He also directed us to a few unique bars that were his personal favorites. In short...Ethan is a gracious host and ambassador for mixologists everywhere. You will enjoy your visit here and leave with a quenched thirst for both libation and knowledge if so desired. If not, you will have a terrifically crafted cocktail in a bright and friendly historic bar.
author: John B.

description: Great happy hour spot!  The company I intern with reserved the upper floor for us after hours one recent evening, and it was perfect all for us away from the crowd and chatter down below.  We could hear each other talk, cocktails were tasty and made to preference, and the ambiance made for a nice evening spent.
author: Maile N.

description: Beautiful bar, excellent bartenders. I've been here many times and always got excellent cocktails for which I always felt undercharged. Came here very drunk a few times and the bartender politely refused to serve me, but offered to page me a cab. Classy, old school. Friendly place.
author: David M.

description:
I find house of shields to be an okay place to hang out.  I was a bit miffed by $12 drinks and really lax service.  But I can't get everything I want, right?

It's a rather narrow space, but extends along the front of the building, and maintains a classic look with tile floor, wooden booths, and a bar that has wooden shields embedded into it.  The vibe of the space is a little odd - a place that hearkens back to a previous, simpler time where boozing was done in secret and illegally, but falls short of the charm of some of the other speakeasies in the city.

It certainly has classic drinks like moscow mules in copper cups, and a pretty good old fashioned.  The thing that irks me a bit about this place though, is that sometimes I can feel slighted by the service, like when I tried to order two old fashioned and it took 15 mins to get them!  I know drinks can take a while, and I know I should be more patient, but the drink is also $12!

I expect to have to wait at Zeitgeist, and I expect to be intentionally demoralized there when I go to order, but I think the classic watering hole should have a slightly higher bar for service!
author: Alex H.

description:
Certainly interesting bar.  They don't trust you with their mugs for mules unless you leave your id...damn thieves ruin it for everybody.

Met some Yelpers post Yelp Gold Soiree, as if we didn't have enough to drink at the event.  That probably speaks more for us as drinkers and not as Yelpers.  But we are known to pre-drink, drink at the event and post-drink which happened here.

According to the signs, it was one of the oldest bars in San Francisco which I don't doubt since the washrooms were pretty old.  There is a lounge space on the upper floor but not too big. 

As oppose to another bar I visit the next day, it's not divey or stinks of urine.

Plus, it's in the financial district not far from Union SQ where most of us were staying.  No one wants to be driving after too many.

Cool place, I hate to see what it looks like in daylight since most older bars look harsh in the afternoon light.
author: Melanio F.

description:
I would give it 3 stars because it's acceptable/satisfactory and not mind-blowing. But I will give an extra star for its historical significance and for being 2 blocks from BART, which is rare for a San Francisco bar.

If you don't know the history, you should look it up because it will make this bar more interesting. A U.S. president supposedly died here.
author: Jason C.

description: I mean, I came here for an alumni happy hour so I had a ball. The bartenders are friendly. Would I come again? Maybe if in the direct area or I worked nearby?
author: Victoria C.

description:
This historic bar is the kind of gem we are missing in San Diego.  In SoCal everything is about being clean and modern - this place couldn't be more the opposite - in a good way.  I can imagine coming here often to escape the gloomy SF weather.  The best way to warm up on those foggy San Francisco nights is to crowd into a booth, order a few drinks, and engage in some interesting conversation.  I enjoy a bar where you can actually hear what your friends are saying.  It can sometimes be hard to find a place where you can even hear yourself think, let alone talk.  

Some nights are meant for rowdiness, others are meant for casual drinking - this is the place for latter.
author: Jocelyn A.

description:
What a cosy, quaint, cute spot! 

After an evening of amazing food, getting lost in a mirror maze, and way too many bad jokes, we stopped by House of Shields for a drink. Walking into this wooden haven of old timey San Francisco was a delight, and I felt like I should have brought my porkpie hat and perhaps a cigar (unlit, of course) to fit in! This treat of a spot has intimate little booths that we squeezed our group into, then ordered our cocktails and beer from the bartender. My cocktail had elderflower in it (I can't remember what else), and was tasty. The prices are reasonable, and the service prompt and efficient, especially for being quite busy.

I feel like this is a bit of a hidden gem because it looks almost divey, or super stuffy from the outside, so I hesitate to write this and reveal my secret... but you guys probably already knew about it, right?
author: Ayla C.

description:
If this place were hidden down an alley rather than in the middle of downtown, it'd be better.

If this place weren't the Go To Spot for every working stiff in the general vicinity, it'd be better.

If you could arrive at normal drinking hours and snag a seat, it'd be better.

If you could actually order a drink after 5pm, it'd be better.

That said, it's still pretty great.

Rumor has it that President Harding died in this very bar, and was dragged via underground passageway to the hotel next door (I'd like to take credit for making it up, but the rumor-mill is here, among other places: http://www.tablehopper.com/lush/house-of-shields-opening-this-thursday/). I arrived early with friends to try to get a seat; we half-sat half-stood for a few hours discussing a) exactly where the President may have died, b) what may have caused his mysterious death, and c) whether or not he consumed as many Side Cars as we did. The party stopped early, though - as the crowd got thicker, we stopped being able to converse due to the din, and the wait to order a drink from the overworked bartenders became 7-people-deep. 

Just remember after your order your scotch on the rocks to pour a little out for our dead prez.
author: Ray J.

description:
Midnight cocktails on a Friday in SOMA with some co-workers. Where you gonna go?
House of Shields, baby!

The bar was lively but nothing too overwhelming. It was an interesting mix of hipsters and SF characters (young and old).

My co-workers and I occupied a cozy booth and drank the night away. 

The bartender was a bit on the surly side. I could tell that he was training or working with a bar-back that he wasn't particularly fond of, so his annoyance was quite noticeable. I stuck with ordering simple drinks (eg Fernet and Tequila) lest I have to wait a long time.

All in all, it was a fun city night at a cool bar with some great peeps. What more can one ask for?
author: Kevin B.

description:
On a low-key weeknight, I don't think there's a better choice in the neighborhood than this old-school spot with its dark and intimate vibe. I'm told the bar's been around for over 100 years, and I can believe it because they don't make massive marble urinals like that anymore. You could weather a nuclear winter crouched in that thing.*

The bartenders know their business. Although they can make pretty much any craft cocktail you desire, I highly recommend the Gold Rush. This bourbon, honey and lemon concoction is perfect, especially if you're fighting off a sore throat and you need an excuse to justify drinking. Unless you have five to seven of them. At that point, you don't have a leg to stand on and since it's Monday, you might be a borderline alcoholic. 

Anyway. Not only have I enjoyed every drink I've had at the House, but when a friend didn't enjoy her choice, the barkeep took it back and comped her next one. That sort of easy and accommodating service goes a long way toward return visits, and I'll certainly be back.
_____________

*I got in there just to scope out the situation. I didn't smell great afterward, but I felt safe.
author: Peter D.

description:
The Drink: Hibiki 12 year, neat.  

The type of scene:  Darkly lit bar.  You bump into a drunken and boisterous young man, who was making friends with a couple seated at the end drinking whisky.  You are there to comfort a friend, who bumped into her ex-bf.  

The Hibiki, positioned in front of you gets gulped down by the young man, who tells you that you have beautiful eyes and lovely lips.

He bargains with you over math equations.  

He ends up losing and paying for the drink that he drank and another whisky.

Good selection of alcohol.  Professional bar-tender.  Not super crowded.  Tavern like feel. Caters to tourists and locals alike. 

Be prepared to have  your butt grabbed and your drink gulped down by some crazy 20 year old from Modesto.  Don't ask.
author: Hiromi N.

description: One bar tender on Saturday is not enough, there needs to be one more. Some trashy drunk women were very hostile at the bathroom yelling and pounding on the door incessantly saying they wanted to fight me when I was in there for less than 5 minutes. That's the caliber of people you'll find at this place. Be warned. Drinks were just ok.
author: Breee R.

description:
Sorry, have to give a low rating here...  Walked into the bar and the bouncer laughed at my ID for some reason (not sure why...I suppose I'm kinda funny looking, but never had that happen before.  I think he said I was smiling too much...).

Found a table upstairs and made camp.  It's a very dark place, but that's not so bad really.

Headed back downstairs to get some Moscow Mules.  They mumbled something about an ID then ran away with mine.  I was kinda confused, but the ladies sitting next to me explained it was collateral for the mugs I was about to get.  They brought drinks back sometime a few centuries later.  We drank them...in the dark...  It was...well, it was.

Went back to get my ID on the way out.  Gave them the mugs, paid, got "my" ID back.  Left.  The next day I noticed they gave me back someone else's ID.  Guess I should have checked better, but seeing as I told them my name and this guy was named "Josh" (and looked nothing like me at all)...I feel like it shouldn't have been too hard, really.

The bartenders had zero personality.  They seemed kind of annoyed to be asked to make something for me. 

Overall, not impressed.  I'll go somewhere more fun.
author: Brian B.

description:
This is a pretty good spot for grabbing those well deserved drinks after leaving the office. It's got an intimate, low key vibe and it feels classic but not fancy. You'll find plenty of people in suits, so do not expect the hipster crowd. They have a small but interesting selection of drinks and the barmen are pretty good at their job, meaning your 12 USD per glass will probably not be regreted.

If you fancy a beer, then this is probably not the best spot for you. They do have a few, but they are not so interesting and their prices not so friendly. All in all, I'd say this bar works for catching up with friends, enjoying a nice cocktial.
author: Gabriele J.

description:
Say what you want about this place, it's definitely one of those after work spots where everybody knows your name. But for our crowd of SF visitors it was the perfect spot for us to gather after a long day of work sessions to kick back and have a well crafted cocktail (or three).

The fixtures are classic and maybe a little dated, but come across fancy and refined as opposed to crusty and old. The staff are masters of libations and make stellar cocktails and recommendations for those less experienced cocktailers.

On my second visit to HOS, what really won me over was when we were granted access to their upstairs lounge area for our larger group. Can comfortably accommodate a group of 10-15 with a mix of seated and standing room. It's a step up in terms of sophistication from the already swanky main floor, with fancier leather chairs and couches.

Totally worth paying a visit to if you're in SF and are looking for something to wet your whistle
author: Kris U.

description:
I've been coming to this Old School San Francisco bar for years and it's always been a favorite of mine to meet up with friends for drinks. I needed a little pick me up on Friday after a long rough week,  we found ourselves at the House of Shields. 

The door man greeted me and told me that I looked beautiful. It put a smile on my face ten miles wide. We were able to find seats at the bar immediately and had no problem getting good service from the Bartenders. They mix some great drinks, but don't even think of asking for some froofy flavored vodka drinks, they don't carry those.

We ordered Manhattans with Makers, Bulliet Bourbon and Rye, Trumer Pilsners and should have ordered more water - Oh my. I think I may have over indulged a bit.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
It's a perfectly fine local haunt for all who live in SOMA. Direct and to the point, cocktails are trad and good, staff are pros and fast. Quite personable, too, but when it gets busy (which is happy hour hour) let them ply their craft. Convo is a luxe, at the right time. 

But if you need a bite, p'raps not the place to land. But, hey, it's a fabulous bar... If you wanna eat, go next door.
author: S L.

description: This place seems so dark and dingy. Definitely not my kind of vibe, but it's conveniently located in FiDi so I can see why it fills up on most nights. I like that there are booths instead of tables (makes you feel like you can hang out with friends and share dirty little secrets) and there is also bar seating if you prefer that. There is not much else to say about this place. It's just... your average bar. Meh.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I love this place because it's so chill. It's not one of those bars that put up a front, like we're chill until 11pm hits and then we'll put on some EDM. They're really just straight up, like their drinks!

I ordered off the menu and got a very well made Negroni and Bee's Knees. Judging by the drink menu I felt safe doing that. I did that once at a similar place and felt like a dummy because they just stared at me blankly. No sort of thing here, no judgement!

 Consistency is key, and they keep it real every time!
author: Rachel C.

description: Love the charm of this bar. Met Keith who is a great mixologist....loved his creativity with our drinks. They were yummy.
author: Lydia T.

description:
I come here for the bartender Shanti, who makes the illest drinks in town. No doubt the Sazerac and Moscow Mule are a staple fav of mine. If you ask him about whiskey, make sure you take your notepad out because he's going to you to school.

This is a low key kind of bar. It's a place where you can catch up with old friends or pre-drink before you the hit clubs.
author: JF K.

description: Amazing bar by the Bart station at Montgomerry. The ambience is really good for a bar. Dim lights and a candle on your table. It's great to have a good conversation with your buddies over drinks.
author: Dheeraj M.

description:
Ah, this place takes me back to a galaxy far, far away when I was a puppyish ad agency worker bee hanging out with the rest of the hive downing happy hour beers at the one big booth on the ground floor. I didn't know chef Denis Leary was the one who masterminded the much-needed refurbishment of this legendary watering hole. He's responsible for Canteen and more recently, makes his signature sandwiches down the block at his other eatery, the Sentinel. Rumor has it that he opened the Sentinel in order to get dibs on the lease for House of Shields. The effort was well worth it. 

The place looks much improved as if it belongs at the Palace across the street. Dark woods, antique chandeliers and Greek-style sculptures that complement the light fixtures - all the touches brings an old-world veneer that doesn't feel old-fashioned (see photos). The clientele is mostly low-key thirty-somethings from what I could tell. Gratefully, there are no big-screen TVs and no pub grub menu to distract from the unadorned cocktails they serve here. My standard Maker's Mark & Ginger was $7.50 in case you're wondering. Jamie W. and I enjoyed hanging out on a late Sunday afternoon in one of their mini-booths for two. 

DRINKS - 4 stars...potent potables at downtown prices, no food which turns out to be a blessing 
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...nice job on the remodel, really highlights the grand architecture of the Sharon building 
SERVICE - 4 stars...they pour 'em up just fine 
TOTAL - 4 stars...a genuine comeback for a place where you now want to socialize
author: Ed U.

description:
No happy hour is really surprising considering the area. I was meeting a fried here otherwise I would have gone to any of the hundreds of other bars in the area. 

Service was fine- only had one glass of wine. Not to be choosy but at a price point of $10/glass I'd like to know what type of wine I'm drinking (ie: what is the name of the winery?), rather than just the varietal.
author: Alyssa J.

description: always open, it seems (it isn't, actually, it's just that everything else in SoMA closes really early). there are multiple booths that can fit 4 to 6 people and a long stretch of seats at the bar. it's also one of the few bars in SoMA that are open on Saturdays, in case you ever make plans in SoMA because you mistakenly thought that the Japanese place above John Collins is open on Saturdays...
author: Meryam B.

description: Good drinks. Nice classic bar. Bartenders are rude as can be. Perhaps it's a new "feature", but this place used to be all-around good. Latest bartenders throw attitude about everything. Pay with cash? [Eye-roll] Ask for some napkins? "They're on order" [walk away] Compliment on a well-made cocktail? [eye-roll and walk away]. Luckily there are a million other great places to drink in San Francisco.
author: k g.

description:
Not a whole lot to add that hasn't already been said, but this place uses to be a speakeasy back in the day. The architecture is absolutely stunning. They really took time to preserve the history of this beautiful bar. 

The bartender was very sweet and patient with our large group. They have beer, wine, cocktails pretty much anything you could want. I opted for a beer which was only $3 bucks! Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area.
author: Cindy G.

description: Would have been five stars if it hadn't been for the heavy metal tunes. I'm a Tommy Dorsey fan myself.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Great atmosphere! 

It's a bona-fide bar in all respects! Everything from the seriousness of checking IDs at the door, to the bartender mixing the drinks like a licensed mixologist, to the professionalism of service that is given.

I got the Moscow mule, that was mixed with premium vodka, fresh lemon juice (from real lemons squeezed right in front of you) and ginger beer. Did I mention you can get it in a cool cooper mug (nice touch)?

My only complaint is our bartender.  He was very professional and was a genius at mixing drinks, BUT... he was cold and aloof... not qualities I would like in my bartender or anyone who's in customer service. 

Finally, although I'm only visiting San Francisco, this is a place I could see myself or others going to after work for happy hour.
author: Marti M.

description:
Best Moscow Mules ... or as bartender Patrick says, they're "magical."

Bartenders from other bars like to drop by at House of Shields.

Creepers are at a minimum here.

This is not a bar to bob your head to Top 40s tunes and get down. The music (often wordless grunge or rock...so it sounds) is tuned down so you can engage in conversation and enjoy your stiff drink. 

Being right across from the Palace hotel, you can except some out-of-towners but for the most, I think it attracts a regular crowd (one that my girlfriend and I are determined to become a part of)

Come and chill.
author: Kat C.

description:
Bar goin' up.........on a Monday...on a Tuesday...on a Wednesday...on a Thursday...on a Friday...

Okay, so you may have gotten the point...that House of Shields is a fun place to come out--no matter the week night. One of the best places my coworkers and I like to spend time after work downing a few moscow mules and then some... btw, if you're going to order a moscow mule, the bartenders will have to keep your IDs until you return your glasses! 20 happy snaps for whomever can guess why! ;)

Anyways, House of Shields makes a pretty wicked Moscow Mule...but they always have plenty of other beers on tap, wines, and specialty cocktails for you to order. There's a good amount of booth seating on the main level + bar seating, but they do have an upper level with more seating. It doesn't seem like they open the upper level until Thursday-Friday evenings when there are more people.

Drinks are pretty decently priced and they taste good. :) It definitely gets loud and crowded here come Thursday-Friday...but hey, it's a fun and social place to be. Bartenders are cheerful despite all the bustle around. 

Will continue to be a regular here!
author: Rachel C.

description:
We stopped by here, early one evening because it was professed to be one of the more hidden, not-as-touristy gems of the city.  And it didn't hurt that it was in close proximity to where we were staying. 

House of Shield is very dimly lit.  Very very much so.  Which is pretty neato if you happen to have ugly friends, which I wouldn't know anything about (so just kidding).  There were a few booths, but we chose to situate ourselves at the bar.  

The bartender was kind of friendly - briefing us on the recent renovations, the new ownership of Shields, etc.  I don't recall what I had, but it was fairly light and delicious.  I am assuming this is more of a cocktail bar than anything, but I get the feeling the bartender wouldn't be opposed to mixing up some stupidly simplistic cocktails.  

It was not especially crowded on this weekday, a very relaxed and homey kind of feel. 

I will say I do recall the one-person restroom being a little bit snazzy.  Not sure why that sticks out in my mind, but just so you're aware!
author: Ellen C.

description:
I was trying to go to Local Edition but it was closed so my friends and I were looking for another spot to get a drink--we ended up at House of Shields.

This is a cool spot in downtown/financial district San Francisco to grab a drink after work. I went with a Moscow Mule--they have the copper cups (I guess a popular way it's served). I've had it served in a martini glass at this Russian restaurant in Washington DC. I might be back sometime when I'm wandering around the area and need a random drink.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Super unique decor- reminds me of a mansion- maybe a haunted one!! :)
The bartender was AWESOME (we were in on a Saturday night) He was so friendly, and funny. He seriously made the bar experience - I would go back for him!! Drinks were standard. Bar was very fairly empty, which was nice in the hustle and bustle of San fran!
author: Meghan D.

description:
House of Shields is a sexy, old-school bar hidden over on New Montgomery. From what I understand, it used to be a long time hangout for journalists who preferred rum-soaked, smoky bars to bull pens. These days it's been upgraded with dark wood, super classy fixtures, and craft cocktails. The crowd is a mix of hip upscale folks, business types and cocktail aficionados. It's 100% my kind of scene. 

The super tasty craft cocktails and sophisticated vibe are enough to make any kitten meow. Small intimate booths and a long dark wood bar would add up to make for a romantic setting but the vibe is too busy and loud for that. It's more of a great lively spot to catch up with friends over an El Dorado (their version of a Hanky Panky with Martin Miller's gin, Carpano Antica Formula vermouth and a dash of Fernet Branca). 

I only spent about an hour here but it was easily enough for me to start crushing hard on this bar. Add in that the drinks are only $10 and that's all you need to say.
author: Don B.

description: Wow I don't know what's up with the stingy star-givers but this place is the coolest!!!  The tall booths, the jazz music, the glorious lack of TV's and sports - it's a real gem (if only they brought back the mod dance nights to get a better-dressed clientele...).
author: Kooky B.

description: Showed up around 10:30 tonight with a group of six friends, we sat at a booth and waited about 15 minutes with no service. A friend went and asked the bartender about drinks... Specifically ones on the menu. The bartender told him that he was in the wrong bar. We didn't know how to take this so we left. The more we talk about it we believe it may have been a bit discriminatory but I'll leave that to your imagination.
author: Chris J.

description:
A go-to standby for happy hour along New Montgomery, House of Shields brings old school charm to the post-work crowd that frequents it. 

Cocktails in copper mugs is a nice touch but I typically end up getting pints here but they do have a decent selection of brews - not extensive but sufficient. Come for something special mixed by the bartenders.

The main ding is that the bar does get packed fairly quickly and seating is a challenge. That and trying to find a spot along the long bar to get the bartenders' attention. Otherwise, House of Shields is a decent spot to catch up with folks over drinks.
author: Jon L.

description: Nice old style bar.  Have been here twice while in SF, have enjoyed myself both times.
author: Greg T.

description:
Now this is my kind of bar. The kind of bar that is cool, but not pretentious. The kind of bar that isn't trying too hard, that isn't trying at all actually. The kind of bar where it's up to you to make the evening remarkable with your shining personality and choice of drinking compatriots. Of course, the bar is willing to provide the sparkling wines, sudsy brews, and delicious cocktail concoctions that make the setting. (Or even just a sparkling water for those ladies that might be expecting, but still want to hang out with friends.) 

House of Shields is a quiet, cozy, comfortable space with tall booths, an open bar area, and a dark, vintage-y atmosphere. It's the kind of place that's good for a weekday drink, a happy hour get together, or even a non-rowdy weekend night. In short, it's the kind of place I'd probably spend a lot of my time at if I were still living in San Francisco.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
This is a cute, quiet bar, perfect for catching up with an old friend or even taking someone on a date. The bar itself is spectacular. The woodwork is incredible and from what I understand, it's original to the building? Not totally sure but definitely worth checking out.

The back bar was small and the spirits selection was somewhat limited. I like scotch though and without being too picky, there were a number of scotches to be had. The cocktails were also great and my friends and I enjoyed a few hours here hanging out and catching up. I'd definitely pop back in for another drink if I'm in the area. Not really a destination bar for me... As in I wouldn't go out of my way to come back, but it's pretty close to my office so odds are I'll be there again soon enough.

The doorman was extremely kind and forgiving when a friend of mine was a little too tipsy. The bartender wasn't too amiable but made a decent drink.
author: Katy H.

description: This bar is the perfect place to chill with friends.  We came on a Friday night and it wasn't too crowded and the atmosphere was good.  Lively but I wasn't overwhelmed by it.  Perfect!!  And my vodka soda was only $5.00.  Seriously?  Why aren't I there now?  I will return!
author: Alisa M.

description: We found this place in the area of where our Hotel was. It is very cool inside, diverse crowd and a very knowledgeable bartender! He could really mix up any concoction you can think of or just tell him what you like and voila he's got something special for you. Love the old, cool decor and lovely chandeliers. Great Place to bring out of town guests!
author: R. B.

description:
Favorite bar in SF. 

Awesome atmosphere, great selection of whisky and wine, and the most accommodating bartenders. Perfect spot for after work drinks, first dates, and girls night out. LOVE!
author: Michelle N.

description:
Nothing wrong with ordering a few glasses of champagne here with some gal pals. Who cares if it's Monday night? We don't see each other often and I was tasked with finding a bar that was cool, quiet, served good drinks and within walking distance of the W Hotel. 

Easy peasy! House of Shields it is.

10 minutes later we were inside a big booth, boozin' it up. Only a few drinks 'cause it was a Monday night, but House of Shields is always a good choice. :)
author: Abby S.

description:
Like the classy girl I am, I came right when it opened at 2 pm on a Friday.

That's normal, right?  

Trust me... I deserved it.

House of Shields sure as hell wasn't empty on a Friday afternoon.  Now, it wasn't crowded by any means, but I was surprised at how many people were already there .  I think I was the only female.  The inside of this bar looks exactly like what you would think "House of Shields" would look like. 

Anyway, the bartender was pleasant.  We talked to him about scotch, and he gave us a little background about the different kinds that he had.  Either I'm easily impressed or just an idiot... or both.  

In any case, it's a fine bar that doesn't try too hard to be anything.  Check it out!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
House of Shield was a disappointment when I first came here years ago. Dets is in my previous review. I may have come here before on the wrong days, because Monday and Friday has always been an excellent experience lately; not for anything else but for some really good drinks. Happy Hours are the best time to come in those days (Monday and Friday), never fail. 

This has become one of my favorite, especially now that I am working in the city, few steps away.
author: Lora M.

description: I was here over Thanksgiving weekend.  It was pretty empty, but I didn't mind because that meant my friends and I could snag one of the booths.  My glass of wine was pretty large and pretty good (I got the Cabernet)
author: Kelly M.

description:
I like this place -- it's unassuming, and cool in that whole "I really wasn't expecting this place to be this cool" sort of way. 

It's not about the flash, that's for sure. Really low lights, really dark wood, really high ceilings: this place feels old-world and untouched by time's inexorable march. (Too much? Too much?)

At any rate, it's pretty rad. Their printed drink list includes some nice beer selections, wine/champagne, and more "traditional" cocktails (the Tom Collins, Moscow Mule, etc.). That said, I have the sneaking suspicion that if you were to ask the friendly gentleman behind the bar to make you something not listed, he'd be happy to comply were it possible. (Note: I had a pretty delightful bourbon old-fashioned.)

Ten bucks a pop for specialty cocktails, and as far as other price points? I can't speak to 'em, since I wasn't paying attention.

Go! See! Check it! You'll probably like it.
author: Rachel F.

description:
We went here on a Monday, after another bar around the block that was particularly disappointing. Walked in and I thought it was kinda narrow and dark, but the positives were sloooowly revealed.

I mingled a little first, not knowing what I wanted to drink. I went up to the bar and hovered while the bartender made someone else's drinks, hoping for a suggestion or a drink choice to come to mind. 

Then it was my turn. So much pressure, I still didn't know what I wanted, but I didn't want to miss out, so I asked for something pisco-y, since that's what I drank last. He, Patrick, the bartender, made me a pisco capa-something, a different version of a mojito. It was great, and it was about 6x as much drink (basically a full pint glass) as the last bar for almost half the price ($8). There's muddled lime in it, which I was worried about. I don't normally like alcohol with lime, but the taste was very subtle it didn't bother me. I must have really sold it too, because I got someone else to order one... AND that person even bought me a second. Score.

Patrick, the bartender, was awesome. He played punk rock music, he dealt with our huuuge group all by himself (Seriously the only other guy working there was the bouncer, but don't get the wrong idea about the place... not a club.) He's a man wearing many hats: bartender, musician, engineer, and historian? It's true, he told me the bar - this beautiful tall, wooden, antique-y thing, from what I remember through beer-goggles - was about 105 years old. Gorgeous. Check out the picture of the dudes on the wall, too. In addition, I used the bathroom and felt like I 100% stepped into Downton Abbey maids quarters. I kinda didn't want to leave.

Badass bar that I'd totally return to for being the kinda place I'd want everyone to know my name. (...Except of course that one stranger who said something weird in my ear and then was promptly removed from the establishment.)  :)
author: Heidi P.

description:
Hubby said he wanted to hit up a shady little bar in the city and, of course, House of Shields sprang to mind.  Years ago, I used to come here often with business associates and spend the afternoon drinking far more than I should on a weekday.  But, that's the purpose of House of Shields and we weren't alone.

After all these years, the only thing that's changed in the bar is that it's cleaner than it used to be.  I don't mean that it was dirty because they didn't sweep the floors, but the walls and ceilings were coated with years and years of smoking (when they allowed it) and the general dirt that wafts through the air of a small, dark city bar.  When the new owners took over a few years back they cleaned the place from head to toe and now it sparkles with a sheen it hasn't seen in many moons.

They have a few special drinks that will tickle your taste buds, but Hubby's favorite is this drink with ginger beer that's served up in one of their special mugs.  As always, I drink red wine which is good enough quality for picky me and served in a glass that reminded me of a mason jar.  Charming!

So if you're looking for a nice place to have a few drinks that's not one of those chain bars or a chi-chi corner pub, House of Shields serves up good people and good drinks.
author: VB L.

description: Literally stumbled across this cool joint while wandering the mean streets of SF one night, and it was instant love. Great vibe, great bartenders, great (and tasty and creative) drink menu. I shall return!
author: Blaine W.

description:
They only have a few different cocktails at a time and they aren't crazy unique, but its a moderate price for a small classy bar in upper Market.  

A little pricy to drink here all night but its a great place to start a night and grab a sophisticated drink and chat with a few friends.
author: Steven H.

description:
Old school bar that has been around for a LONNNNNGGGG time.  There could be ghosts in there, but this bar is cool :)

Classy cocktails, great liquor selection, and a couple of their bartenders/mixologists make amazing drinks... ask for Patrick or Ethan - highly recommend!
author: Brett B.

description:
This was a nice place to stop by for a couple of drinks in a local pub. It's so close to the bart so it makes it so convenient. We got lucky and grabbed the last table. It's quaint with a loud atmosphere so be ready to speak up. The lighting is quite dim in the bar as well as in the restroom, watch your footing. 
The bartenders were cool and drinks were very strong! I had 3 drinks and they totally put me on my behind. My kind of place! If your ordering the Moscow mule be ready to swap your ID as an incentive to return the cool golden cup. Too many people swiping them apparently. 
Totally will be back next time I need a super strong drink in the city that is just steps away from the bart.
author: Ness V.

description: Nice ambiance for a small space. I grab Whiskey Sours here all the time. Cool dark decor and not pretentious .
author: Cecilia D.

description: House of Shields is a great example of what a bar would have been like when times were simpler.  There are no over the top craft cocktails, loud tvs, or trendy gimmicks.  I'm surprised they even have a website.  Things are simple here: booths and stools, an old wooden bar, and reasonably priced drinks.  Beers ranged from $5-7.  The atmosphere on a Friday night was busy, but with noise levels suitable for talking with friends.  If I was looking for a casual bar to kill a few hours with a group of friends, I would definitely consider coming back here.
author: Mark A.

description: A genuine landmark. Pardon the expression, a real man's bar. Stocked amply with local spirits. Try a Junipero martini.
author: John V.

description:
Look, this is a bar. Service is good. Come here to meet women.

The end.
author: Joshua H.

description:
Here's where I think the confusion comes in for House of Shields: trying. In a city where owners spend millions on remodels to make a new breed of bar and then pretend depserately that they're not trying, House of Shields is quite the opposite. Architecturally, it's in kind of a gorgeous space and has the bones to be a really swank spot. But that's just because of who they are and who they've always been. And when it comes to trying, well... they're just not *trying* to be anything other than a bar that pours you drinks.

Were it me, I'd probably fall into the trap of adopting a gimmick. Go with the history of the place. Or the old school sipping lounge. Or dive bar. Or one of countless other things that bars try desperately to be known for without revealing that they're trying to be known for it. But kudos to the HOS peeps who just let the chips fall where they may and serve drinks.

This is not to say that they don't have a reputation or a feel. Every bar has a vibe, and theirs is an after work hangout to grab drinks with friends. Slide into the tall, deep booths and get a quick whet for your whistle or sit up at the long, classic bar and let the fella there take care of you. (Perhaps there's ladies too.. I dunno. It was a fella when I went.)

I didn't see any of the infamous bike messengers that Yelp tells me the place is known for. Or too many suits from Financial District folks headed home. What I saw was a cool bar with a warm, come-as-you-are feeling as folks sipped drinks with friends.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
After a nice dinner at Wine & Wall, our group wanted to keep the party going, so we headed back to our hotel, the Palace Hotel, and looked for a nearby bar.  We found this place, which was across the street....perfect, we can drink all we want and not have to worry about driving or a taxi!

A group of 16 of us saddled up to a corner of the bar and a few of the booths across the way.  It was around 10 pm on a Tuesday and it was not very busy.  With business so slow, you'd think we'd get awesome service....nope, our bartender had a bit of an attitude and was slow to get our drink order and subsequent rounds.  At first, we didn't think much about it...getting slammed with 16 people at once can give some people fits.  

However, we began to feel the attitude on the 2nd round of drinks....so it became a game to us.....let's see if it's a particular person he doesn't like....so we would send up different people to the bar to order a few drinks to see which one was most successful....nope, he didn't discriminate, he didn't like all of us....LOL  It was unbelievable because we rang up one hell of a tab and it didn't seem to matter....

But wait, a few regulars enter the bar and *whammo* they get served properly with smiles and laughter....ok, I get it.....large group of business men & women staying across the street at the large hotel....*phoey on them*....they'd rather take care of their regulars.  That's fine by us....wish we would've been warned, which is why I'm writing this review.  We didn't feel welcome at all here....and that was with a tab that was well in excess of $300+...oh well.

Return Factor - 0%
author: J D.

description:
Suits. Suits. OMG. Suits.*

Yeah, so... suits. You're waist-deep in the Financial District and you're getting a drink after work. What else do you expect? The bar itself (like, physically) is fairly impressive. It's been around since the early 1900s and the history is apparent. No clock. No tvs. Just booze. I can dig it. The gigantic wooden bar is as imposing as it is amazing. This is the kind of place you'd like to just walk around, take pictures and think about the ghosts of drunks past.

But people come here. People work here. Here's where the House of Shields falls down. It's a bar. In the financial district. It's packed. But, again. Expected. It's a bar. In the financial district. The problem comes in when said people populating the bar tend to run over you as though you don't exist. That is, unless you're wearing a suit. Suit. OMG. Suit. I used to wear suits. I still have a lot of them in my closet. Thankfully, I don't wear them as often as I used to. Thing is, I don't think my in/visibility had anything to do with wearing them. This cloak of invisibility followed me to the bar where I waited close to 20 minutes before being served and then after my order was taken, the bartender 'forgot' about me. I was with some other people and I didn't want to make a scene... but, yeah. Drinks served to other people who ordered after me. Bartender didn't come back my way. He didn't even look at me. It wasn't until a colleague flagged him down to ask about my drink that he remembered he even spoke to me. To be fair, the drink was free and it was a damn good Manhattan but I would have rather paid for it and received it in a timely fashion from someone who gave a damn at recognizing that a real, live human being was in front of him asking for the chance to give money in return for him providing a service. Silly me. Next time, I'll wear a suit.

*http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wCF3ywukQYA
author: Johnny T.

description:
The Moscow Mules in copper mugs are indeed pretty good, but letting the bar hold onto your drivers license to have the "privilege" of a copper mug isn't. This is apparently the House of Shields' response to some douchebags stealing their mugs, and it soured my experience.

I'm otherwise a fan of the Shields' ambiance and drinks, but not a fan of this recent treatment of Mule lovers.
author: Steve W.

description:
Let me begin this review stating that I am a whiskey drinker, and a whiskey drinker only.

Yet when I am at the house of shields, I will throw my standard Jameson and ginger out the window, and get my drank on with their Moscow mule, which is hands down the best I've ever had. Like that Drake song.
author: Jenny U.

description:
A small, quaint and chill bar in downtown.

Came here with a friend the other night after hopping around the area. It wasn't too busy, a couple people here and there, in and out...

The bartender was attentive and the drinks were mixed well.

It had an old, dark feeling which was interesting too.
author: Tiff C.

description: Fantastic Moscow Mules served properly in a copper cup (just don't steal it please).
author: Sanel S.

description:
House of Shields feels like it's been in business forever. It has a real pub vibe, crafty cocktails and there's something very genuine about it. It fits into a hip category, but I get the impression that it's just doing what it's always done... and those certain things just happen to be extra hip at the moment. 

It's probably where I would hang out on the regular if I worked in the Financial District on the regular. 

I've never had a bad time or a bad drink and I've been several times and ordered several drinks (usually of the gin or bourbon variety). Sometimes the staff can be overwhelmed by the rush of a big group (the nature of the drinks requires a little bit more detail), but they get the job done pretty efficiently no matter the scene.

The best place in the house is on the upstairs level, so grab your drinks and make for the sky. In comparison to the European-ish pub downstairs, the rattan furniture in the 2nd level make it feel like somebody's grandpa's cabin... which is fine by me.
author: Annie D.

description:
Great chill bar to grab some drinks. And they do indeed have shields chiseled into the wood. My friend told me to try the cherries, and I pass that tidbit on here. They're a bit too sweet for me to be deemed awesome, but if you love sweet cherries with a bit of booze, try them out.

Edit: Came back a different day and got a totally different, but equally good experience. Was much more crowded and loud, but still a great place to hang.
author: Ron H.

description:
The Moscow mule! Probably the only place in the city that still serves them in those copper mugs. That and the special sauce these guys add - what a difference it makes. 

Ambience is a lil darker but I like it that way and be warned it gets packed after-hours, Wednesday through Saturday.
author: Mario S.

description:
This review is for their HAPPY HOUR only!

I've been here a few times for Happy Hour with friends and coworkers. It's a pretty good location (close to BART) and kind of along the way to the bus station.

Not much on tap, but they do have a Irish Cider in a bottle which is a common brand,  not bad. 

This place gets PACKED for happy hours. I've been here on Wednesdays, Thursdays, Fridays..and it always gets packed by the time I get there. The good thing is that there are booths for you to catch up with friends and mingle. Upstairs has been roped off every time I've been here, but there is a decent amount of seating if you can manage to get here before the 5:30-6:00 rush.

They're pretty well staffed too..so you don't have to wait TOO long for a drink.

Really laid back environment with an older feel. Kind of gives it a dirty feel. Why is that? Not quite as open as John Collins a couple blocks away...but it's a nice atmosphere.

LOVE the hooks on the bar for purses/murses/bags..is this standard now??

Not great for huge groups unless you get here before 5 (even then I'd say the max is about 7-8 people)...but good, chill place if you're just meeting up 1-2 friends. :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
It's one of those bars that you often pass by. You don't have time to go it, and you think it looks a bit shabby from the outside. Months may go by and you repeat the above. Finally, one night you go in and you discover what you've been missing out on for a long time. 

Dark. Wood. Stocked shelves. Competent bartender. An always diverse crowd. It's the kind of place one could get lost in, and I'm. It talking about the size. 

Conveniently located across from the famous palace hotel, this place has every thing going for it. There is even an upstairs mezzanine where you can get extra close if needed. 

A most go to place of you are in the area.
author: Chad G.

description: This was my favorite go-to watering hole after work back when I was in the city. Definitely a different vibe than most bars; no TVs or even a clock! This place has some fun history and is just a chill place to go and enjoy a great Moscow Mule.
author: Marisa P.

description:
Pretty good place--waiters are helpful, and do seem to care how much you like your drink. They don't have the widest variety of drinks, but what was stand out about this place is that the waiter wanted to make sure I got the drink exactly the way I wanted (how strong), and even checked in with me 10 minutes later to see how it was.

It's a good place to catch up with people, drinks aren't the most exciting but the service makes it worth going back to.
author: Chrissy H.

description: Get a Moscow Mule here. They are known for it and it's a must if you go here. You'll need to give your ID in order to get the drink. Guess they have a lot of people try to take the copper cup. Busy here during happy hour but pretty quiet on the weekends.
author: Amber O.

description: Nice spot. Cool bartenders. And they had some great bourbons behind the bar!
author: Mike G.

description:
While I was slaving away in the FiDi, House of Shields was my after work sanctuary. The location is perfect for the startup crowd, the finance crowd, and everyone in between thanks to the BART station in close proximity. It fills up fast around 5pm-7pm, but there's usually quick turnarounds as people head off to their second (or fifth) bar, so snagging a barstool or a table isn't too difficult.

The soundtrack's always fantastic, the bartender has a heavy hand (I've introduced many friends to Hangar 1 here, and if you haven't had it, ask for it), and it doesn't delve too far into faux speakeasy like EVERY other bar in the neighborhood these days. 

Best part, for those of us who live in SoMA, it's open on the weekend! Way too much in our backyard closes all weekend long, so this is my go-to spot whenever I need a cocktail on the weekend. Congrats on the 5-stars, you earned it!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Finding a spot to sit/stand during after work hours can be quite a challenge, and especially so if you're planning on coming in with more than 4 people. 

That being said, House of Shields is still one of my favorite go-to places for all things bourbon; case in point, I always recommend people to try their Old Fashioned. It's made just the way I like a traditional Old Fashioned. 

Atmosphere-wise, the place has a nice Mad Men feel to it, where the bartenders all have waist aprons and you never have to wait too long (even during their busiest hours) to get yourself a drink. 

I highly recommend all my friends (and even you!) to give this place a try!
author: Tiffany H.

description: A great hang with friends, I really loved the vibe in this place. Old world decor and super laid back, this is a unique bar in the Financial District with crafty cocktails and low light. I was here for only a short time, but the mezzanine overlooks the entire bar with fabulous views all around. Though the lighting was a bit low for my liking, when combined with the dark wood and bankers lights, I felt like I had stepped right onto the set of a gangster movie. Think banker, investor, business suit meets comfy casual sophisticated cool. Though I only had a diet coke, I have to admit the mixed drinks looked sublime.
author: Angela S.

description:
There's something to be said for weekday barflies; we can be persnickety. That being said, The House of Shields is my go-to weekday spot in the FiDi.
