HoS possesses most of the qualities that I look for in a solid weekday bar that keeps me returning. First, the crowd. There really isn't much of one. Don't mistake that, though. Come on a Friday or Saturday and it's as packed as many SF bars, but on a weekday, you'll find a fair amount of collars along with a sprinkle of women. 

That crowd leads to the second good weekday bar quality, the ability to carry a conversation without needing to expose any of the veins in your head. The music is varied in genre, never bad, and presented at a level to create a landscape or theme to conversation. Which is nice because it allows for the opportunity to engage with the people around you, friends, strangers, and bartenders alike. 

Hence, the third quality; an unpretentious, familiar ease. The decor of the bar establishes its presence with its vintage, grand decor but doesn't upstage the activity it invites within.  Rather, it frames it, making even any inebriated patron look stately. And this unpretentious, familiar ease extends to the bartenders as well. Not only can they make solid drinks (in particular, Shanti and Eric), raising conversation and introductions come as free-flowing and tasty. 

A real gem of a weekday bar.
author: Shirley T.

description:
A classic old-timey bar with well-made drinks and awesome little booths.

Stopped in here for the first time in a long time on a random Tuesday night around 10.  Love the ambiance of the place... dark wood molding, mosaic tile floor, classy old-school light fixtures.

I had an Old Fashioned and the bf had a Dark and Stormy.  Both were well-executed.  Bar service was a bit indifferent (but not negative) which from reading some other reviews tends to be a running theme.

Definitely on the list for those times I'm downtown and in need of a sip.
author: Kevin F.

description:
I use to frequent House of Shields a lot in the past, mostly because I stayed at the Palace Hotel across the street when I visited the city. In recent years, I've stayed closer to the Embarcadero so it's been awhile since I last had a drink at HoS.

Well, this past weekend, I made a return trip to HoS and it was my first trip since their remodel. The decor is pretty much the same, they seemed to clean things up and made a few minor cosmetic changes behind the bar.

In the past, they use to have live DJ's on the second floor balcony, and it served as  a "venue" on Friday and Saturday nights. Those days are over, from what some of the regulars told me, the owners wanted to "class" things up and get rid of the Art Academy crowd, so the live music stuff is doneski. Which is fine with me, I kinda liked the new setup, and the drinks were great. The bartenders were friendly and quick to serve. 

When I arrived at 8:30 p.m., only a few of use were there, but things quickly picked up at around 10 p.m. and it was pretty much standing room only. 

I plan on returning here when I visit San Francisco next month.
author: Henry F.

description: Beautiful place. Moscow Mules are off the hook. Excellent service. Nice atmosphere for chillin before game time!  Stop in and check it out.
author: Lisa M.

description: Drinks were on the expensive side at 10 bucks a pop. I got the Moscow mule which I actually really enjoyed, very light, refreshing and not too sweet. Not on the menu but very popular apparently. My friend got one of the cocktails on the menu, was a little bit too strong for
author: Ada G.

description:
Would give this place a 3.5. A little nicer place since they remodelled. 

Pros: Great beer selection. Really strong drinks. Nicely remodelled and reasonable prices w/ good service.

Cons: For happy hour, there is a lack of tables. Upstairs randomly had this huge standing up area with no tables.
author: Karen S.

description:
This bar seems like old San Francisco but I don't think it's really that old. My coworkers hit up their happy hour and were happy. The crowd was a mix of after work crowd and some people from across the street at that fancy hotel.
I had a couple martini's and that was enough. They were made well enough that I didn't frown.
I might come back again sometime
author: Lizzy M.

description: Great drinks and very professonal bar staff.
author: Michael M.

description: Good ol' HOS right by work.  The go to before going to somewhere else.  Staff is solid but never necessarily above and beyond.  As much as coworkers and friends say we should stop going here, it's just such a staple in the bars around Montgomery BART station, which is crucial for a quick drink and hop on home.
author: Nadia D.

description: HoS has always been an after-work cocktail favorite of mine but I've never gotten around to reviewing it! I've noticed that it gets packed right after work and then is totally dead in the later hours. So, if you're headed there after work your best bet is to show up early and snag a booth. I recommend the seating upstairs if you have a bit of a larger group but your group will have to go back down to the bar for drinks again (which can kind of be a good thing if you're footing the bill). I recommend their specialty, the Moscow Mule, but be forewarned that you'll have to let them hang on to your ID so that you don't steal their coveted mugs. If you're not in the mood to part with your ID try just about any other drink because they do them all well.
author: Chris W.

description:
We went fairly early on a Monday and were pleased to find it wasn't packed. The place is pretty attractive now but a bit brighter than I expected overall, which detracted from the atmosphere for me. I was surprised at how small the drink menu was, which made me feel like I was missing out on something. We did enjoy the 2/3 of the cocktail menu that we ordered (skipping the margarita), so that's the main thing.

I guess my expectations were too high, because while it's fine, I wasn't impressed.
author: Lisa K.

description:
It stands to reason that I came to House of Shields with a bunch of writers.  This is just the kind of place that appeals to literary, romantical types -- the kind who generally need a strong drink at the end of the day just to blunt all the feelings. It's also the kind of place that lends itself to literary, romantical descriptions (apologies in advance).

The main features of this dimly lit hideaway are its high ceilings and high-backed booths, both which seem to invite mischief and whispered secrets. You can imagine someone taking their illicit lover here, or skulking off to drown their sorrows after being jilted at the altar. 

The bartenders play off this mystique, and aren't afraid to act like characters in a short story. They'll tell you the sordid history of this place if you ask, and all while mixing a mean drink. When I ordered "something like a Manhattan," the bartender responded, "So, does that mean you want me to make a Manhattan, or does that mean you want me to be brave?" 

"Be brave," I said. Wouldn't you?
author: Ryan W.

description:
If I lived in SF, I'd likely be a regular at House of Shields. It's got loads of history: over 100 years old, kept open as a speakeasy, and rumored that President Harding actually died within it's walls. Pretty impressive stuff. 

The bartender was friendly and provided a history lesson with the properly poured (and impressively inexpensive for SF) drinks. I liked the large yet open booths: as we found, they invite new friends in to the fold. Soaring ceilings, beautiful wood carvings, and just the general atmosphere ooze comfort and swank. Unfortunately, the Creedence Clearwater Pandora station that was on kind of did the opposite. 

Get new music, folks.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I moved away from New Jersey at the end of middle school. 

I started over. New friends. New life. 

After I graduated High School my mom moved back to New Jersey with my brother. During college breaks I would revisit the house I pretty much grew up in from Elementary school to Middle School.

Walking around our small town - it felt so strange recognizing faces I had once gone to school with. Seeing everyone so grown up. So different. Seeing that everyone had moved on.

When I walk into House of Shields I feel that strange enveloping feeling of both confusion and nostalgia.

I rarely go to House of Shields. Not just because I don't really drink. But because it never really felt like me. The lighting was always a little too dark. I always felt a little out of place. The service was always a little off.

But what did bring me in here was close friends and co-workers. Since I first started working at Yelp - House of Shields was that random bar that meet-ups took place in. It was that random bar - where you would see people you hadn't seen in months. It was a place where you embraced people you cared about and remembered.

I can't say I'm necessarily a huge fan of House of Shields and that I would ever think to come in here by myself. But I have much respect for this place for being a unique stand-out bar in the downtown area. For having a distinct charm and decor. And for being a constant through the years.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: Good cocktails. Service left something to be desired. One bartender on a Friday night? Also mixed up an order. Cool, old school decor.
author: Ethan P.

description:
Air Mail - original house cocktail A++

House of shields is right by where I work, so it was convenient to hold my 23rd birthday party here with a few of my coworkers. The best part is that I didn't have to pay for any of my drinks and I had quite a few! I stuck with the "Air Mail" all night and it was great.

The bartender was very friendly. I love that it was the first time I shocked a bartender into how many drinks I could take. Every time I lifted my finger to ask for another, he got more and more surprised.

Awesome bar, but if I hadn't gotten comped for my drinks all night, it would've done damage to my bank account. Not the cheapest bar if you know what I mean.

Easily accessible bathrooms and not too crowded. They also have a variety of interesting original cocktails. More of which I would like to try!
author: Junel S.

description:
The saddest thing about this bar, is that I only found it on the last night I had in SF. Boo. 

Things that instantly make me love a bar: 

- Wood! If it got wood, it's got me (ahem)
- Good booze
- Booths! (i'm easy pleased sometimes)
- Great vibe

This place had all the above in spades and has me a tad sad that I've had to leave it behind without hitting it on more than one occasion.... and maybe being a tad more sober as I roll through it's doors!
author: Chris D.

description:
Been coming here on and off for years.  So glad it is under new ownership, and the bar program is now worthy of the beautiful historic space.

One of my favorite rooms in the city, and now has legit Classic Cocktails!
author: Robert P.

description:
A nice FiDi bar for meeting up with others after work or popping in after dinner to hang out with friends.  

A great place for beers and standard cocktails, but not a great place for fru-fru cocktails of the moment.  For whatever reason they didn't have any amaretto so the bartender suggested another drink that contained the same elements I enjoyed in my initial order.  That was a nice touch.  Most places would have just had me order something else.

Drinks are ordered at the bar; there are no servers.  I loved that the place did not reek of stale beer and seemed clean and tidy.  Empty glasses were picked up with efficiency.  Booths and stools are available for seating.

The space is really dark inside, which adds to the desired ambiance, but I felt like I was in a cave at times, or the Haunted Mansion at Disneyland.  The high ceilings add a lot of drama, but do nothing to supress the noise level when it gets crowded.  

This bar has some interesting history (ask the bartender) as a speakasy.  A solid choice if you are looking for a drink and perhaps some conversation.  Eclectic crowd adds to the experience.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Shopping is scientifically proven* to dehydrate your tissues and lead to an excessive need for a restorative alcoholic beverage. Especially when Occupy decides to shut down Market and generally cluster-eff up the general area. So it was with great relief that my mother and I ducked into House of Shields at the completely cocktail-appropriate hour of 3 pm.

We've eyed this joint every time we're in the area because the actual bar - you know, the part with all the booze bottles - is gorgeous. Rich wood, marble counter, solid and massive construction. Much of it's original (1903!) but it's been restored and cleaned up to its original glory. And I've got to point out that the young gentleman behind the bar was distinctly attractive as well, which never hurts. We asked for any kind of gin cocktail he felt like making and to my great pleasure he busted out fresh-squeezed lemons and the St. Germaine. Really, it's like he read my mind. Prices were reasonable, conversations were free-flowing, the clientele were friendly - this is a wonderful place to cure what ails you. 

*My scientific method may be flawed.
author: Corinna K.

description: This is hands-down my favorite bar in SF.  I love the staff, the cocktails are amazing, and the laid back vibe ensures everyone feels welcome.  My favorite times to go after happy hour when it has cleared out a bit and I can sit at the incredibly crafted and restored bar.  I recommended giving the bartender your spirit and flavor preferences, and then completely surrendering yourself to their masterful cocktail-making.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Cortney E.

description: Cool atmosphere, great bartender. I couldn't decide what I wanted so I asked him to make something with bourbon..I do this often in bars and I was pleasantly surprised that he made me something I had never had before. A black manhattan..don't ask me what's in it, but I can say it was delicious! Also, they have Guinness on draft which isn't always the easiest thing to find!!
author: Cristina H.

description: Love this place, great bartenders, historic bar and not too trendy.
author: Teisha F.

description:
I remember years and years ago as a kid this was a dive amongst dives- like Tenderloin grade dive, with black paint over the windows. It closed down and figured for sure it was going to become a Sandwich place or whatever. 

Now it is a great old bar with awesome decor and great drink selections. What is also cool is that is seems like a neighborhood bar where a bunch of patrons and bartenders all know each other on a first name basis. Don't see that much at a downtown bar...
author: Jim B.

description:
HoS is a clean venue but too many flaws for me to want to come back here:
-Gets too packed too quickly
-But the worst part are the drinks/bartenders: the bartender skipped me 6 times even though I was standing right in front of him (if there's someone with boobs standing next to you, they'll serve them first no matter how long you've been waiting). Drinks taste like koolaid (lack of alcohol), and for what you get, the drinks are definitely pricey.
author: Vik B.

description:
This review is basically for the room and its architecture and appointments.  As I am almost always a driver on bar outings, I don't sample much of the creative output.  What I drank was banal and not worth comment.  But the place...

This place is a terrific reminder of times past in San Francisco.  The details have been extraordinarilly well preserved, from ornate ceiling work to the mosaic tile floor, the bar itself and the seating.  

It feels like you are in a working bar museum.  A nice alternative to "branded" bars.
author: Bob K.

description: Really chill little dive bar.  Not crowded at all aka boring.
author: Kim T.

description:
This little gem is a hole in the wall.
Grab a friend, then find a spot in one of the booths, order a Moscow Mule and then talk the world to rights.

This spot reminds me of bars in Berlin and London - good times.

Situated right near the financial district it always has a good few suits in there - but it's a cool, relaxed, un-judging crowd.

Be warned - it is a small place, get here early to grab a spot - Good excuse for daytime drinking!
author: Hannah K.

description: Old school bar.  Nothing fancy which is nice in a city where bars try to do too much these days.
author: Blake B.

description:
I've been here a couple of times for post-work happy hour with office colleagues.  As suggested by other reviewers, if you want a seat, it's important to arrive early.  Arriving early is easy to do because one of the best things about this bar is its hours of operation- it opens at 2P, which is three hours before most other bars in the financial district/downtown.

However, i just discovered that the best way to enjoy this bar and beat the crowds is to come on Sunday!  I went this past Sunday with a group of about 8 people.  It was easy to get a seat and we received expert attention from the bartender, Patrick!  I had a great time and will definitely visit again.  Sunday is the new happy hour.
author: Jamie A.

description:
Located inside the historic Sharon building with great decor and architecture. It's a very unique bar and it's cool like dat....dig it? 

On Friday and Saturday nights, they have live bands or DJ playing good music...good, free music. Their music venue is located on the second floor with a great view of the bar area. 

Good place to hang out, down a few cold ones and unwind after a long, stressful work week. It's near the New Montgomery BART station and Market St. Muni line so you don't have to drive home if you had a little too much to drink.
author: John G.

description:
Awesome architecture. Aweasome vibe. We went after a Giant's game it was pretty dead, but I'm def going to check it out again post-work for Happy Hour. 

Great location.
author: Katie K.

description: It's an institution worth seeing...I tend to bring out of towners here for a more realistic SF experience.
author: David S.

description:
Get here early.  We skipped out from a lot of hot air over at the Moscone center to sit back, relax, and talk about the week.  No problem finding a seat right around 4, but the place filled quickly and then became overcrowded, making it difficult to order drinks #3 & #4.

Good selection of beers, my coworker from Portland was happy with the choices.  I had old fashioneds.  The first was amazing.  The second and third, made by a different bartender, were just okay.  Nothing wrong, but there was some special mojo in that first one.  It could be first drink of the afternoon syndrome, but I don't believe so.  I do like the sour cherries they used for these.

They even made a decent margarita.  I am always suspicious of bar-made margaritas.  I don't know why, I guess if I do not see a specialization in tequila, with a frozen marg machine in the background (even though I never order those) then I just do not truest the place to make them.  I did not order this, but my friend did, it was good and she was happy, so all good there.
author: Kevin N.

description: Maybe my favorite bar in the city. LOVE the booth seating, even for 2! Great atmosphere, friendly bartenders. Even the BATHROOMS are badass. Go here. But don't make it the next big trendy thing please. Save that for Rickhouse and Local Edition :)
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I love House of Shields for a nearby, after work drink.

To be honest, there's nothing really special about it. It's really a 3-star dive-bar (in my opinion) but it's worthy of a fourth star for 3 reasons:

1) The bartenders are super friendly and wear skinny ties (I'm a fan)
2) It's small enough to be intimate so it never feels jammed or empty
3) It has a very random crowd, meaning the experience is always hilarious

Check it out if you want to inject some randomness into your weeknight!
author: Heather T.

description: Hole in the wall! Go here after work for a drink with your girlfriends kinda bar. Had a Moscow Mule, read about it on here even though it wasn't on the menu and it was fantastic. Great value too!
author: Kalong W.

description:
I wish someone had warned me about how strong their drinks are, so I'm doing the universe a favor and making it clear right here and right now. That said, they're really good, especially the Moscow Mule! It comes in a shiny bronze mug which does very little to shield your hands from the drink's arctic temperature. 

I like that it looks like an old white person's house too. Just proceed with caution. If you are clumsy like me do not accidentally lean on the emergency exit for support. It will open and the alarm WILL go off.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
I have been wanting to check this place out, but figured I should steer clear of a happy hour full of FiDi suits that I read about on Yelp. It's not that I mind. It's just that I like to be comfortable and actually change after getting off work if I'm hanging out in the city, so I wouldn't want to feel underdressed. 

However, I ended up stopping here with some out-of-town guests a couple Saturdays ago, and it worked out perfectly. We were able to get a seat at the bar, although there were plenty of little dimly lit booths too. 

It was one of our girls' birthdays, and turned out one of the bartenders, too, so he made us up a tasty celebratory shot. I think he was technically off at the moment, too, so that was super nice of him. 

Talk about nice. These bartenders were really personable. They checked on us often enough, and were handy for drink suggestions as well. I like my drinks to be delicious (or one might say girly), and this is kind of a no-frills place. You won't find anything fancy in a martini glass here except for maybe a dry gin martini. So, on one's recommendation, I tried a Greyhound, which wouldn't have sounded good, except he said it would be made with St. Germaine's vodka. I hadn't tried St. Germaine's, but I thought, why not ... so glad I did! My drink, topped with a garnish of three black cherries, really hit the spot. So much so that I opted for my next drink to be the same, and my husband gave it a try as well. 

That Greyhound was so yummy I've been thinking about it ever since, and plan to revisit soon. 

I really liked the atmosphere. Contrary to what some Yelpers wrote, I did not find this place small. I thought it was quite roomy. We were there early so I assumed that was why it wasn't so bad, but I ended up stopping in a couple hours after leaving to pick up a lost cell phone, and it seemed just as comfortable and not shoulder-to-shoulder crowded at that time, either. 

The building was super old, and I thought it was cool. The bathrooms were narrow and dark, like something out of a horror movie. Wouldn't be surprised if the place was haunted, but that wouldn't stop me from hanging out!

The Verdict: A gem in the heart of SOMA with comfortable seating, friendly bartenders, and tasty beverages. What more could you want?
author: Cara S.

description:
Not sure why there is all the hype over their remodeling. I walked in, looked around and just saw a bunch of people standing around, got a weird vibe, and walked out.

It almost seemed like a funeral just took place in there....everyone was just whispering among themselves. There is no music (which for some reason people seem to review as a good thing). Very odd place.

....maybe it's just not my scene.
author: Lester W.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the City! I come here almost every Friday after work and it never disappoints. Eric is a great bartender who knows every drink ever concocted. The atmosphere is a mix of work crowd, tourists, and students depending on what time you come in. You can always count on Ray to make sure the crowd doesn't get rowdy though. The drinks are great and reasonably priced. Their specialty is the Moscow Mule which is too sweet for me but everyone seems to enjoy it. 

House of Shields has a lot of history and is one of the oldest bars in the City. It was recently remodeled and I think the owner did a good job in keeping the old Speakeasy 1920's feel to it. I especially like the wood walls and wood everything pretty much.

The one downside of this place is that they need to play some hip hop. I don't think it would kill them if they played some Kanye or Drake once in a while. Other than that, no complaints. I highly recommend this place if you want to just relax and have a drink after a long work week.
author: Javier G.

description:
05.06.11

Can someone please tell me what they remodeled?  Because everything looks the same to me, and the place smells like urine.

And they serve wine in a whiskey glass.  I get it, I shouldn't be ordering wine at a place like this.  But it was one of those nights where this was only the first stop.

Yet it's still packed.  *Insert puzzled face here*
author: Jenny L.

description:
Came here at 6:00 on a weekday, just like everyone else. As the businessman making out next to me on the booth can attest to, this is the post-work power drinking crew. 

I had a black lager on tap, which definitely could have been colder, but my friend's sidecar ($10) was delicious and the bartender was smiley. 

It was quite crowded with thirsty suits and the tables were sticky, BUT

I loved the old-school vibe of the place, with the high ceiling and chandeliers and whatnot--I felt like I was in the lobby of an old hotel that had a lot of secrets.

I won't make the trip back there just for this bar, but if I'm in the area again at the drinking hour, I might return.
author: Emily D.

description: Wood paneling, cozy booths and crack bartenders offer up a very classic SF experience.  You could drink here and then pop into Tadich Grill for something of a theme night.  Excellent cocktail program, recommended for all your happy hour needs!
author: Patrick S.

description:
Do you like Scotch? Do you like Tequila? Do you like.... having a good time?

This place is great for grabbing a few friends and having some drinks.
House of Shields is my starting point for an epic night. On Fridays there's always a big crowd and the bartenders are always on point.

Last time I was there, I talked to the bouncer(I think his name was Ray) the whole place exudes a welcome atmosphere and a laid back approach. Be warned-- every so often there are dumb people who drink too much and get into a brawl... with themselves... lol

HOUSE OF SHIELDS - THE PERFECT STARTING POINT
author: Nathan B.

description: Came here with some co-workers for happy hour a few weeks ago.  Didn't realize this place was sooooooooo close to the office, were talking 20 steps from my building, lol.  Not a bad hole in the wall.  Place gets really packed at 5.  Good thing they have a lounge area upstairs, since the ground floor was packed.  The bar had an old school feeling to it (probably all the wood).  I ordered a few screw drivers which were made just right - not super strong and not watered down, at $6 per drink I was a happy customer.
author: Mike M.

description:
HOS is my bar of choice if there's ever a last minute, spur of the moment, need for an adult beverage.  It's only a hop and a skip away for me but mainly because it's really chill and sans douche.

there's a good selection of beers from guinness to local IPA brews.  what i have noticed though is a lot of patrons order mixed drinks that are perhaps specialties of HOS?  i've ordered a greyhound once or twice before and it was tasty....but i can't remember if it was fresh squeezed grapefruit juice or not.

the bartendars are relatively nice.  you just have to be patient.

i'll be back.
author: Sally T.

description: I don't go to this bar often.  Happy hour is pretty crowded but over all I like the ambiance and the cocktails are really good.  Cool place to go grab a drink after work before you end your evening. Cheers!
author: Liz D.

description: Nice place. Didn't spend too much time there because no food and very noisy. Great staff but too may people for the 2 bartenders - so long wait for drinks. Bartenders very friendly and knowledgeable. Drinks were amazing!
author: Teri Y.

description: Like all other bars in the city, it's hard to order during happy hour.  The happy hour menu is pretty decent, but I just ordered a Hef.  We were lucky enough to get a booth to sit at which made things easier.  There is music in the background but it was not the top 40 hits.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
You can shine up a place- but if the bartenders don't smile- charge you for a drink you didn't have, it's just another dive. 

My experience Friday January 28th-around 10-11:30pm
I went to see Blue Valentine- distraught, destroyed and shattered I decided that my 2011 resolution of 90 days of one drink a week had to be discarded due to my emotional state. I remembered that House of Shields had just reopened and so I tearily ambled down Market Street to drown my sorrows.

I sit down and ask what kind of beers on tap- un-smiing bartender begins rambling off a list- not even looking in my direction.Halfway through the list- I say, "Trumer please." He continues to ramble all the names- i again say, "Trumer"- He brings me back a beer with a lemon in it. I say,"That's not a Trumer."- He acts like it's my fault and without apology says, "I thought you said Wedmer"...and brings me back a Trumer. Five bucks. I pay, I tip. He mumbles something about a slow night. Drink. Ponder movie. He asks me if I want another beer. I say, "In a minute." I think," Hmm, something stronger." I ask what's a great drink- he suggests a gin drink- I say no, make me a Manhattan. Brings it. Damn good cocktail. 

I start up a conversation with nice gentleman. He offers to buy me another drink- I say sure and he orders one for himself.. Another Manhattan shows up- great cocktail. We talk, totally pleasant conversation. I go out to smoke- and as I'm coming back in my new friend and I have decided to go our separate ways- my friend says, the bartender is worried you are not going to pay your bill. I said, "Yes I'm going back in." I go back in and the bartender tells me my Manhattan is $18.00. I don't argue- I pay. I think,"Fuck, that's crazy."- 

I texted my friend this morning- apologizing for the expensive drink he bought me. He replies, "No I paid $18.00 for both our drinks..." I realize that the bartender is not only unfriendly, a poor listener, lacks social skills, is either really bad at math- or a rip off artist- thinking I would never apologize to the guy the next day for buying me such an expensive drink....either way- it doesn't bode well with me. I rarely write a negative review of any business.

Love the bar- it's always been glorious-but the service is absolute shite. 

Get someone who wants to be there. Period. One, when a woman comes into a bar alone, be nice to her. Period. Bartenders should have an ease about him. This guy was not that...even my new friends mentioned what a bad vibe he had from the minute they walked in. Bartending is a combined art of mixology, class, and personality and this place deserves just that. 

He might want to think about why it was a slow night..Maybe it is him.
I will go back-it's too lovely of a spot not to- but I will be very careful to pay my drinks when I get them.
author: jules m.

description: My first time in the city I met my brother at House of Shields it's really nice inside kinda like stepping into a time machine tht takes u way back when liquor was a nickel lol Bar tender was really dwn to earth .. After wrk hours it really filled up with same great characters I'll for sure be going back soon maybe in the later hours Jst to see the change in characters lol
author: SeXavier S.

description:
Last night was my boyfriend's 25th b-day! Yayyuhhhh baby! While waiting for his 'rents to arrive, we decided to pop in and check this spot out his co-worker recommended. When we walked in it looked like everyone else had the same idea: happy hour, meeting friends after a long day's work, and a whole lotta relaxin'.

++Interior and atmosphere felt positive, lots of smiles and good energy

+/-I told the bartender, "I usually get gin n' tonic. Could you make something deliciously strong with gin, and lime?" Whatever it was, it was very nice and tart! I guess $10 for a drink during happy hour is the "norm"... but I guess since I was smack in the middle of SOMA thats what I should expect for a tiny drink. But.... good thing I hadn't eaten yet because I was surprisingly tipsy after that little green monster.

Conclusion: Cool bar to go to meet up with friends and get a quick drink. Off to the next!
author: Julia D.

description: I like dark, clean, classis Irish bars. This one is great and amazing that this is in the middle of San Fran. Glad the old school charm can survive the bustle of the big city.
author: Rob A.

description:
It's really nice here, except everytime I come here, I can't find a fucking seat. Well fine I guess I come here after work--5ish. But out of all the million times I've gone I can NEVER get a seat and it's stuffy. 

Regardless-great bar. 

Good job with the renovations House of Shields!

Helpful bartenders.

Nice crowd.
author: Thao L.

description:
Live music is always good here and even though it's in the Financial District and you know... Well, you know what kind of folks you'll find out there, House of Shields still manages to keep a really cool spot with a fun crowd and good drinks. Live music is always on point.

The real reason I started coming here was because of their Bloody Mary's!! Damn, these are the best Bloody mary's I've ever had! I love you.
author: Camille R.

description:
Went to the House of Shields for a networking event on a Wednesday night. The place was crowded by the time I arrived at around 6 with the Fi-DI and SOMA crowd.

Our event was upstairs so I had a great view of the layout for the whole place. I really liked the ambiance of the place reflected in the deep wood panels. The upstairs bar was fairly intimate and the noise level wasn't to overpowering. 

Luckily that night, the Glenfiddich representative was there pouring some very generous servings of 15 and 18 year Single Malt Scotch Whiskey. This just added to the whole experience of the place.

Looking forward to the next mixer at HoS!
author: Johnny V.

description:
Yay, it's back! And it's the same pretty much!

This place is a BAR and just a bar. Not trying to be anything else.

Thanks to Dennis Leary for purchasing this bar and not changing all that much.  Can you imagine? Some soul-less corporation coulda bought and gutted the place, replacing awesome character with bland design.
author: Dana D.

description: I loved the vibe of the bar. A mix of classic rock and reggae music, so random but I loved it. We went for an after-work happy hour, which was a little busy, but not too bad compared to other surrounding bars. Definitely had to try their Moscow Mule, which is usually my go-to drink when we go out. It was smooth and delightful.... and very strong. Loved it. Wish they served bar food though.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Great bar.  It was built a very long time ago.  If you walk in, there is a door on the left near the far wall.  It goes down to a big room that used to be used for making hooch during prohibition.  There is also a tunnel from that room that goes under the street to the Sheraton Palace.  Yup, it was used for sneaking the hooch over to the hotel.

You will get your dose of messengers, iron workers, business folks, art students, etc here.  You will also get a chance to order from a full bar with a good beer selection.  I don't know crap about wine, so you're on your own if you want to know about their selection.  

I LOVE the old handmade aspect of most of the fixtures in the room.  Things were made with a lot more elbow grease in those days.  Many of the tiles on the floor seem to be slightly crooked, or at that's what they look like after a martini or so.  The lighting is pretty old timey.  You know, no neon, no halogen, no dialed in atmosphere here.  It's just a nice old bar.  

It reminds me that hanging around in a bar having a few belts with friends is not a new concept by a long shot.
author: Nelson W.

description: Thursday night happy hour with a few co-workers. The place consisted of a few booths along the window with a good size bar, and I was surprised how packed the place was. I think there may have been some sort of an event going on, since the upstairs was reserved. Couldn't quite get the full experience of the place, but one item that worked against this place right off the bat was not having any dark beer, other than Guinness. Nice place, but too small and not enough different types of beer for my taste.
author: Michael H.

description: Moscow Mule! I had to. House of Shields is an icon in SF. The drink menu and the ambiance can't be beat.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I've been here a few times and always had a decent experience. The last time I went was shortly after the remodel. 
We were spending the weekend in the City celebrating my husband's 30th birthday and had gone out for a few drinks after dinner.  We'd randomly decided to drink Mai Tai's and ordered a round in House of Shields. Ok, now I get that this bar is not a Mai Tai kind of bar but I acually would have respected the bartenders more had they refused to make them instead of what actually happened. On the second round of drinks the bartender made the Mai Tai's with tequila instead of rum and then flatly denied it. His attitude sucked and was some of the weirdest and worst service I've ever received in a bar. Don't think I'll be going back anytime soon.
author: Leigh M.

description:
Kudos for restoring this bar to it's historic glory! 

Check out this great story about House of Shields in the New York Times

http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/23/us/23bcshields.html?src=twrhp
author: Karrot L.

description: pretty cool spot. I got a cocktail that was just so-so, sounded good on paper, didnt gel in reality, next time its all about a moscow mule!
author: Drew V.

description:
This is a cool bar with decent happy hour prices ($5 well drinks).  It is actually kind of like the straight version of Twin Peaks in the Castro; it even has a similar layout.  The bar looks really cool because it is all old and stuff, but that tin ceiling really makes it loud.  even though there were probably only 30 people inside it was deafening up in the balcony area.

That being said, the balcony is really cool, and you can reserve it fro private parties, which seems like a good idea if that is something you are looking for.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Want to get slow, surly service in a room packed to the rafters with douchebags? 

Then come to House of Shields.
author: Daniel N.

description: Went here because it was close to BART. Real classy looking place, the bartenders were even wearing ties. He gave us a little rundown about the history of the place. The bartenders knew what they were doing, although the one in the vest seemed kinda douchey, the other one was not. The interior was very dimly lit and it added to the ambiance of the whole bar. The on tap selection was solid, they had a few local brews including Linden street. I didn't have any of the cocktails but they were made pretty well from what I could tell. The clientele is a mix of hipsters and normals with a handful of tourists sprinkled throughout. The booths are comfortable also.
author: Samir K.

description:
Drinks with class.

In a sign of age (or perhaps higher standards), one minute into the nearby John Colins and we were out. Terrible music blaring. Poorly dressed crowd. Debauchery waiting to happen.

Not my scene. Plan B was the new House Of Shields.

This longstanding establishment was recently giving a makeover by acclaimed chef Dennis Leary. The interior is gorgeous. Deep wood palette. Lighting highlighted by chandeliers and lampshades featuring a refined plaid design. Comfortable seating.

All for not if the drinks don't deliver. And they did. Imbibed in a very well made gin & tonic that was crafted by a very well dressed bartender. Class all around.

This is the new Plan A.
author: Jason B.

description: I love ending the day here when I'm in the city. Great old ambiance with bartenders that know how to make a good cocktail. I usually get an Old Fashioned or a Manhattan. So if you are in one of the many nearby hotels, get out of the house bar and give this place a try.
author: David P.

description:
Was here for our company offsite. So, we had the whole place to ourselves. I would have given it 4 stars, but I thought about if I were to come here without having the place to just people you like. There aren't that many tables and the space is small. It does have that nice bar feeling though. A little big old-timey. Not really a space for younger people, but more for workers done with the day in Fi-Di or SOMA.

Their drinks are good though and their bartenders seem to know their stuff. I had a whiskey sour for the first time here, and I was sold.
author: Vera W.

description:
If it wasn't for Brent Simmons I'd probably not go back. That said, next WWDC I'm sure I'll be there, wishing I didn't have to pee out of mortal terror of the bathroom.

Shields is one of those places WWDC attendees invariably end up. Why? Couldn't tell ya.

It's dark, dusty. There seemed to never bee more than one bartender. Really? Just 1? Couldn't they figure out when WWDC was coming and staff up for a week?

The bathroom is absolutely foul. I've been to a lot of dive bars, but none has had as scary a bathroom as shields. It's more like a garbage dump with a toilet stuck in it. 

To quote a friend, "My junk is the cleanest thing in that room"

I felt really bad for the ladies that had to use it when the line got too long for the women's restroom (though I can't imagine theirs was any better)
author: john W.

description:
House of Shields serves amazing cocktails. It serves cocktails where one would want to start/close a night with. And what is great is that I can drink a quality cocktail in a place that has a nice laid-back, low-light, divey vibe.  It's a nice change from pretentious speakeasies or trendy avant-garde restos (Note: I do still love my speakeasies and avant-gardes). 

Gold Rush please! Moscow Mule please!
author: Peter T.

description:
This is my Cheers.  I'm so glad that Dennis Leary took a shine to the place and restored it to its former glory.  The Belle Epoque light fixtures that once looked gaudy and forlorn are quite pretty now.  The refinished wood paneling and haberdashery inspired upholstery add a decidedly 20's touch.  

Super close and convenient + good beer = 2nd home.
author: Monica L.

description:
Lots of young folks who work in the Financial District here, looks like a good place to hang out after work.  I came here with work colleagues for beer.  

This place has a nice upscale ambience with chandeliers and dark wood paneling.  The drinks menu is simple - beers (I had a very good pale ale) and some standard cocktails.  

There is a paying garage next door, and the Montgomery Bart station is within a block.
author: Bee M.

description: I was there only once or twice before the renovations, but I think they've retained the historic feel with a general (but not overdone) refresh. We were there on a Wednesday after work, and the vibe at first was a little crowded and banker-y, but not offensively so. As it got a little later, things thinned out a little and the place had a little more slow charm. As long as you don't mind going up/down with your own drinks, the mezzanine offers some decent space away from the crowds. Overall, recommended!
author: Thomas R.

description:
If you're looking for a line dance, keep meandering, partner.  

I like to gather up with my gang and bend an elbow at this here joint after a long day of lassoing. We chew the fat and have whisky while we watch the fillies trickle in.

HOS is about the business of drinkin' and pleasantries; It ain't about frills or them young bucks and their house music. Just the way an old cowboy likes it.
author: Duker M.

description: I've been wanting to write a review of this place for awhile, so I am stoked that I am doing it. :)  I really like the interior of this place -- it's a really small bar (smaller than I originally thought), and it definitely has that old-time SF feel to it.  The bartenders are snappily dressed, and most of the clientele here are FiDi workers coming straight from the office.  The happy hour is decent (wish it was a little cheaper), but overall really dug this place.
author: Mel G.

description: I like that this looks like a proper pub, but I haven't had the best experiences there. Was there this past Thursday and one of the bartenders was going out of his way to be a dick--not just to my group but he was doing this to others in the bar as well. Not sure his deal, but its enough to keep me coming back in for maybe a year or so.
author: John S.

description:
House of Shields is a great place for drinks. It's pretty small, but wasn't crowded when I went there. There's a beautiful coffered ceiling and the whole place has a medieval feel to it. Behind the bar is some amazing hand-crafted woodwork. The actual drink selection is a little lacking: they only had two red wines available, which was frustrating. They have five on the menu, but were out of three of them. I think they're much more into beer and hard liquor here. I got to try a microbrew from Oakland (didn't even know Oakland had microbrews) which was excellent.

There's a loft upstairs, but I didn't take a look. I did, however try out the legendary urinal in the men's room. Apparently it's pretty famous somehow. It is absolutely enormous, and very old. I guess they're proud of it, like an antique. A nice place to go with some buddies and relax.
author: Ron S.

description:
So our dogs were barking and we needed an adult beverage , we stumbled on this bar. Well Patrick you made us right at home and what an absolutely fabulous time we had. We are the ones who u played Elvis for . You made our day , your cocktails were amazingly yummy and your personality was so awesome. We will be back all the way from Sacramento just to visit at this amazing bar with an amazingly refreshing bartender who greeted each and every customer as they walked in. This is exactly how a bar should be ran. 
See u again soon pat, you've won our business.
author: Anne B.

description:
this place gets free stars simply for serving a moscow mule in a proper copper cup.  it gets another star for being EXTREMELY close to my work.  oh, and another star because the bartender was super sassy to a coworker of mine when he left a few drops of a shot left.

boss to my coworker: "hey man, the bartender said i can't close the tab until you finish your shot..."

coworker: "what? i totally finished!"

*points to shot glass with a few drops left*

AND THEN WE ALL LAUGH AT HIM, mwhaha.

drinking is so cool.
author: Lauren P.

description: Bars in San Francisco start ahead of the game because they are all smoke free! Amazing how much that adds to the ambiance of a place, but somehow House Of Shields retains that dark and smoky vibe without an ounce of smoke in the place. From the name to the high ceilings and deep booths, it seems a tad regal and a whole lotta mysterious. I love the fact that you can squeeze about 6 ladies around a booth and feel cozy. I didn't order a cocktail, but I downed two glasses of soda water delivered for free by the kind bar hop. It was a Monday, and it was very low key. I will say that for a Monday the service seemed to drag a little, but I survived. There was no music, no distractions, just a good atmosphere for catching up with friends.
author: Misti Y.

description:
Given that this place is so close to work, I'm not entirely sure why I've never been here!  The bar is relatively small - ground floor has a pretty long bar with booths lining one side of the room and a very small top floor.  The top floor doesn't have much at all and seems to be the place where DJs (or other music providers) set-up (that's what I'm assuming since I saw a bunch of guys with equipment heading upstairs).

It's a popular after-work/happy hour bar - lots of variety of beers on tap and liquor and at a good price point.  It gets a bit crowded after work, so booths and seats can be tough to find.  After 7 or so, it clears out quite a bit...
author: Wendy L.

description:
House of Shields is my new favorite bar in SoMa. Love the atmosphere, non pretentious crowd and cocktails. The bartenders are always nice (and most of the time cute!). Sometimes it is hard to find seating due to the layout of their small booths, but there is tons of standing room at the far end of the bar.

Minus 1* for no happy hour specials.
author: Seema M.

description:
Really cool bar.  Over one hundred years old.  

Nice old wood accents with great happy hour and beer selection. 

Can get crowded.
author: Bruce P.

description:
$2 PBR drafts.  Count me in.

Totally a dive bar.  Exactly what we were looking for.

Bartenders with attitude. 

Dirty bar and Dirty bathrooms.

Cool kicked back vibe though. I like this bar. Beautiful high ceilings feel a little out of place ... but it gives this dive a little more of a glamorous feel.  Just a lil.
author: Laura R.

description:
Beautiful interior!

When I worked in SF this was often my "Friday after work" place with co-workers.
The drinks were fantastic, bartenders skilled, and the time always flew by...

At some point they even had Polish ubrówka there...  [that's what they get the fifth star for]
author: Basia P.

description:
Awesome place for Happy Hour.  Good and strong drinks after a tough day at work.  The service is great and the crowd that this place attracts are your typical Financial District crowd; professionals.  

Oh, and its a block from BART, so having a little too much to drink shan't be a problem ;) 

Highly recommended!
author: Denise B.

description: I must have walked by this place a dozen times when I first moved here before I went in. Its sort of obscure from the outside.  Once I stopped in though, it became one of our local haunts. Its kinda funky inside, older decor but it has a cool are upstairs that you can reserve if you have group. If you like Moscow Mules, this place makes the best in the city, served in a copper mug to boot.
author: Jen S.

description:
As an AAU grad student who attends classes next door, HOS has become (dangerously) convenient during our 30-minute breaks. With impending story ideas, assignments, and deadlines every week, a few of my classmates and I stop by every once in a while to grab a moscow mule and break away from writer's block.

Talk to the bartenders and manager Eric and listen to the fascinating stories behind the history of the bar. Always entertainment. Plus, you walk away feeling educated (and slightly buzzed).
author: Winnie W.

description: This place is fine. While the bar tenders were helpful and the selection of wine and liquor were abundant there was no place to sit to enjoy my beverage. I appreciated the great drinks, but didn't appreciate continually thinking the drink was going to end up on the ground constantly adjusting for those walking by or needing to squeeze past. The crowded location and classy drinks didn't really vibe in my book. Solid spot, would only go back if I could get there early enough to snag a spot at the bar or in one of the booths.
author: Shanna T.

description: Poor service. Had a gathering planned and they Never bothered to mention the bar was closed until 7:30pm for private event. Then the group was sent to upstairs area where no waitress came around for orders-- our group remained hungry and thirsty tonight. Not a place for me again!
author: Isabel B.

description: Fine craft cocktail but the service... I know it is a turn of the century gentalmens bar but dam can't a lady get a drink? One bartender on a friday night.
author: Josephine R.

description:
Even after renovation, this bar still seems to be the bar of somewhat polished types, be it young ex-fratboy financials or young not-quite-real-fratboys-bicycle "hipsters".   

Therefore, the place is loud. What a surprise.

The cocktail "Stinger" is like gum and candy. Don't order it.
The cocktail "Gloss?Golden? rush" is citrussy but with Bourbon. It's OK.

I wouldn't call this a dive bar.. nor a sports bar, either.
author: Jordan G.

description: Stopped by for just a drink.  Bartender was very nice and helpful.  Kind of pricey but what can you expect.
author: Edward L.

description: Two visits on my recent SF trip, which translates to convenient, affordable, low-key watering hole. Our group was able to get a table, put in an order, and even pee without a wait. Plus: Guinness poured correctly. It's a dimly lit, sort of moody ambiance; not flashy, but still interesting. With easy-going barkeeps, and a modestly diverse, well-priced list of brews, it easily measures up.
author: Christina G.

description:
Very laid back place. Old school interior without the stuffy crowd. Stuffy air, maybe.

The crowd is a mixed bag; there's a bike messenger crew rubbing shoulders with some office monkeys that are eyeing the cute law and art school crowds that gather round for the cheap booze. What's that spell? Good times!
author: Wes T.

description: You'll pay less than $10 for a Tanqueray G&T, so this place is a nice pre-game stop before heading out the clubs. It's comfy, cozy and low key. No need for fancy dress or pretention of any kind. My kind of place for a quiet night out with besties.
author: Teresa G.

description:
This is the kind of place that is conducive to epic nights.  

The kind of nights where you go out on a Tuesday,
the kind when you teach a foreign friend how to order "PBRs," who subsequently orders them with reckless abandon for the sake of ordering them,
the kind when you have a drunk friend (girl) use the men's bathroom with you then puke everywhere,
the kind when run upstairs and sing karaoke then crank the system till it feeds back, 
the kind when you then drum on the table until a few full beers fall off,
the kind that leads to sending friends on random missions to procure other "things" to keep the fun going.

Ahh yes, House of Shields, good times, good times.  I deduct it one star because it was pretty much a festival of sausage, but I guess what else can be expected when it's all business peeps.
author: I I.

description: Visited from Montana. Awesome bar, great cocktails. Our bartender Matthew was excellent. His moustache really made me feel like I was in a speak easy during prohibition. Would definitely visit again
author: Parker W.

description: Remodeled to look old. Very convincing. Gorgeous space, tasty old fashioned.
author: Eric W.

description: Ray and the ray-man(amazing champagne cocktail) rocked my world. Definitely a repeat offender at the historic bar. Attentive bar tenders and great atmosphere.
author: Emily S.

description: Good pours and funny bartenders.  Perfect nightcap. The woodwork inside is just beautiful.
author: MrsCynthia M.

description: I love this bar for a few reasons. The interior is gorgeous and sends me back to a time long ago. Shields never seems to be too crowded, although it is very small. The bartenders are overworked but courteous and aim to please. I asked my bartender for a pisco sour last night and although he had never made one, he found an egg, read some directions and made a teriffic pisco sour. Kudos to him and his outstanding customer service.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Smells funny in here, but the beer tastes the same!

Great for an after work or during work drink. It's surprisingly crowded during the weekday afternoons, which makes you feel better about being an alcoholic.

Still waiting to meet the mysterious Schlomo -- supposedly if you find him (and check in on Foursquare), you get a free beer.
author: Lauren H.

description: Everytime I come I here I always drink scotch. I don't know why but I just do. The bartender knows his drinks and I always come here when I'm in the area and feeling sipping on a drink with a friend. It's kind of dark there but it also provides a cozy feel.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
Louder than bombs is one of my favorite club nights anywhere.  For a5  buck cover you get all the morrissey tribute that you can handle.  The crowd is completely decked out and the music is all morrissey and smiths stuff.  The drinks are reasonably priced for the location, and the event brings an awesome group.

On an average night the drink prices are still  good, and the crowd is usually regulars and the after work crowd, but the morrissey tribute night is really the way to go esp if you want to toss on a slim suit and slick up a pompadour.
author: Harsh K.

description: House of Shields has become one of my favorite places to go on a Friday after a long week of work. It's a little on the pricey side, but I love the crowd; Its a lot more diverse than the bars I usually hang out at. I love the vibe& the people that work there are very easy on the eyes (well, some)... Especially one particular 'door man' or 'bouncer'... whatever you wanna call them.. HOLLA! Just sayin'. Best part is that its down the street from where I work.
author: Cat M.

description: It's OK. Nothing memorable. They had some decent beer on tap. The floor of this place reminded me of a urinal. With that being said, this place is good for a quick beer.
author: Marc E.

description: Surprisingly cool place. Based on the sign and my view from the sidewalk, I'd written it off as either another lame-o investment banker bar in the Financial District or else a soulless place that wouldn't be fun to hang out in. It's actually quite nice, with high, turn-of-the-century tin ceilings, dark lighting, dark wood, and dark booths. It's also clean.  In other words, a perfectly old-school San Francisco bar that flirts with feeling sophisticated. They've got a nice hoppy IPA on tap as well as a full bar with all the fixins. Nice place.
author: Julio A.

description: Interesting, classic old style bar just off market. Great collection of whiskey and bourbon not found in most bars. Only downside is the music. Some fun special drinks with fresh citrus.
author: Doug K.

description: This place doesn't even deserve one star. Sadly I must rate it one in order to share my awful experience. I walk in with a couple of my friends both male and female. As we walk in the bartender doesn't acknowledge us. Umm... Okay. How could you not see us? You only have one table and the bar is completely empty. So, I say hello and ask if we could see a bar menu. First thing that comes out of his mouth is "trying to close at midnight" with an attitude. It wasn't even 11 o'clock. He was rude. We ignored his rude comment and tried yet again to start a conversation and he ignored us. Isn't that part of your job? To talk to us? You might as well say get the heck out and leave. Don't be a bartender if you can't handle hospitality. After he ignored us we got up and left. We spent our money else where. Never coming back this this stuck up place ever again and I'm making sure everyone I know avoids this place. Spend your money else where. I wish I would have gotten the male bartenders name.
author: Erika J. P.

description:
Pretty standard bar-type bar. Stranded between 2 neighborhoods, this bar gets some spillover from the FiDi and the mission street bike messaging ne'er-do-wells. Definitely cooler than some of the available places in the area, and definitely not as cool as others.

The bar itself is run of the mill with typical offerings and typical knowledgeable but short (attitude-wise) SF bartenders. Definitely not as friendly as places like Rye, but definitely more friendly than Zeitgeist or Tornado.

Try it if you have no alternatives, but if your friends are elsewhere, go meet them- don't tell them to come to you.
author: Jarrod B.

description: I love HOS! My absolute favorite happy hour spot. I think it is one of the only bars in SF that everyone who goes there has a good attitude. The bartenders are super nice and don't mind that my friends and I are loud and demanding. Great guys serving great drinks!
author: Dee O.

description: I'm no longer a fan. It's not that the little spruce up wasn't badly needed, it really does look nice inside & it isn't as dark as it used to be, but it is just too crowded & waaay too loud. I'm sure it thins out after happy hour but it's just too much. I have visited twice since they reopened. The first time I could barley squeeze up to the bar to order so we left after 1 drink. The second time I left after I realized I was yelling just to talk to the person right across from me. Having a 4 person conversation was impossible. Not my scene.
author: Erin S.

description: Nice place to have a drink after the baseball game. It looks like there is only Guines to drink, but they have a wide selection of beers. The interior of this bar is amazing. There are tables and booths. The booths are really comfy. Prices are fine and it's cozy.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Kelly-Joe is the best bartender ever. You should leave your office right now ands head down there. 

Kelly can ease a long day with a cocktail or two and sure is easy on the eyes.
author: Sean M.

description:
Mixed crowd, like they say.
Biggest urinal ever. 
Wet your whistle there.
author: Brian J.

description: Definitely not my scene. Looked like a meet & greet for older singles. That was my first impression at least... A stella was about $6. It was very dim and super loud, but there wasn't even a lot of people. Well, that was the end of it. On to the next one! John Collins.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Was one of the only places/bars that was open late (meaning pass 10 pm) on a thursday night. I went here after the Sneak Peak of "I hope they serve beer in hell." We went here with Tucker Max. It was pretty fun. 

However, I'm not here to write about that experience. Instead I am suppose to write about this bar. There bar has a decent amount of places  to sit. Bartender is a bit oblivious sometimes. I was standing at the bar for 20 mins at a time waiting to get a drink. I think our crowd consist of half of the place, and it seems that this place has more males than female. 

A nice place to grab a drink, but nothing more.
author: Jimmy H.

description: The renovation is nice, the place feels a little more mellow than before it changed hands, and the staff was pleasant.  There's nothing amazing about HoS, but there is nothing wrong with it either.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Good cheap place to grab a beer or four in the evenings. Dark place, bathrooms are always clean, just down the street from the muni, suits there after 5pm.

Bartenders always seem cool and one of the better dive bar around.

A stable in my bar list but I also only every go during the week.  No idea what its like at weekends
author: ORLA L.

description: Stuffy. Its really the only word that comes to mind. The drinks, to start, are not over priced, but defiantly priced too high for something that is not special, or made well for that matter. Not only from the bar staff but those around me there was a constant feeling projected on me that i did not fit in, or really belong there. Maybe they were right. Its only redeeming factors have only to do with the beautiful classic interior work, the history, and a pretty cool rest room, but if I'm not mistaken its what happens at the bar that makes it a good bar... it is not.
author: Sean MC E.

description: I would've really liked this place if it didn't take us an hour to get a drink. Because of this issue we decided shots and strong margs were the way to go. Oh geez...was there any juice in the marg? Me and Tequila are not friends anymore after this night! Besides this super annoying drink issue, the place itself was cute and fun...especially nice b/c we had a big group (of awesome Yelpers) and we were able to sit at one of the comfy booths. It also has a cute little upstairs area which would be good for groups too. There were also some hot ppl to look at, so that's always a perk! So basically if you're in the mood to wait forever to get your drink than this is the place for you.
author: Sonya D.

description: Amazing that this place is open so late in the Financial District.  We came here after a ballgame to meet up with some friends.  The atmosphere was cool and felt the crowd was late 20s to early 30s, so a bit above our age.  There seemed to be some grad school social going on because one of the booths was filled with backpacks.  So the place seemed cool but the drinks were ehhh.  My friends were carded at the bar, even though we were carded to enter in the first place (isn't that how most bars work).  I guess they looked super young in the eyes of the bartender, but it caused them to lose their place in line for a minute so that one of them could grad her ID from our booth.  Also, she hated the shot she ordered (I unfortunately can't remember what it was a shot of) and thought it was overpriced--and this was coming from a New Yorker.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Nothing gets me to drop my pants faster than cute boys and The Jesus and Mary Chain. This place has both. 

Sometimes you have to wait a bit for the bartender - they're not really in a rush. But they're friendly enough and the the drinks are strong. 

Great spot to meet friends who need to be close to BART.
author: Suge K.

description:
So there's this bartender and her name is Michelle.  I'm going to make this review short and sweet.  I ordered a double jack and coke and if you've had drinks with me before you know I like them extra strong... like filled to the brim of the pint glass with Jack.  $9 that's like $4.50 per, that's like OMG I'm about to get Blitzed, crazy Lit, El twisted'O...

Lauren S, "G what'd you get?"
G, "She poured me a glass of fire over ice"
Lauren S,"you should write that in your review."
Matt H to the rescue with his note pad and pen to make a note of it incase I forget.

So if you ever want to know what fire over ice taste like... hit me up at a DYL. Just Blaze!
************* ***********
update like 5 minutes later

Oh so my point about Michelle is that she was lovely ;0)  Took care of a Brothas needs
author: Jamal G.

description:
This is an update to my previous review about the terrible bartender who threw a glass at us on Tuesday, 8/5/08 (amongst other things like smoking in the bar, cursing at us, etc). Well HOS' owner, in a true professional manner, got rid of the bartender and is making it up to us. I had to change my rating b/c it's not fair to downgrade the bar b/c of one person ruining it for the entire establishment. HOS...you're back on my awesome list like you were before this one crappy bartender who's now gone (hopefully from every establishment EVER!). 

I'm back in love with you, HOS.
author: Melissa C.

description: Cool bar from early 1900's.  Great drinks.  No food.  A complete throwback. Stop in fir a stiff drink.
author: Matthew B.

description:
This is your basic, bare bones dive bar. No TVs, no pool table, no video poker. Just booze and some booth seatin'. 

My kinda of place.

Oh, and there's also that ONE drunk guy passed out in the next-to-last booth.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
Sometimes, you have to ask yourself....

"Self, does it get any better than walking into a bar and seeing a man sitting at the bar knitting?"

Self thinks not, unless of course you want to factor in a well-poured Belvedere and soda, a cool crew of co-workers celebrating the 12 nights of Christmas drinking and of course plenty of people to silently judge (in a festive way, mind you).

Yeah, I dig the House, or is it the Shield, or the HOS, who knows, but I like this place and it holds a special place in my heart since this was the bar that my yelpin cohorts took me to to celebrate getting asked to join the ranks of the yelpin madness back in June of '06. Awwhhh, who knew then, how awesome life could be.

*sniff sniiff*
author: Stephy S.

description:
I like this place.  Usually it is terrific - however, it was awful last night.

The bartender is the worst bartender I have ever encountered.   She was awful.   Painfully slow  - forgets our order (twice) - walks away from the bar for a long time - and makes us ask for the check three times.

What are they thinking?  


For the first time -- ever -- we left ZERO TIP.   She sucked that bad.

Next time we are going somewhere else for drinks.
author: mario w.

description: If you're not in a hurry, and you don't mind a slightly limited selection, this is a-ok. But it takes forev to get a libation. It'll be crafted, but it'll be a while.
author: Corey D.

description:
So I was one of the patrons that had a glass thrown at us.  The event is over, the owner talked to us and all is good.  If you read our reviews we have had no issues with the bar before, just this particular night with a particular bartender.  

All in all, if I read the story I'd probably have a strong opinion of what transcribed and it would resonate with the large BS everybody shot us.  In all actuality, we were calm, sober and enjoying ourselves until the end of the night. 

Its been really interesting to see everybody's reviews of how we are whiny marina girls/guys or how we asked for mojitos and cosmos all night long, its been a great read the past two days.  Here's the deal, we ordered beer and vodka tonics all night long, nothing out of the ordinary I say.  Hell we even had a couple of people taking advantage of PBR on tap, not many places in the city serve it.  

As we said originally, we all enjoy the bar but just that one experience was not fun...as anybody could agree.  HoS doesn't deserve the 1 star rating, so I wanted to change that.
author: Aaron G.

description: Ah, House of Shields, I was so excited that you had reopened, but I felt like I had just walked onto the set of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers--" some alien life form took over your body, and now it looks like you and talks like you, but it definitely is not you.  Your crowd is now more i-banker than IT; you raised your prices for no apparent reason; you cleaned everything; you got rid of the music; and you got rid of the potato chips!  Who are you, and what have you done with my House of Shields?
author: Sydney H.

description:
None of the bartenders even flinched each time i asked for a water.  They just about dropped what they were doing and went and got me my sober liquid refreshment.  Even with a lemon!!

Cozy booths allowed four or five to sit where only two should, and larger booths let those not wanting to touch sit and be comfortable too. 

They have a weird balcony thing where a band can set up...and because the band is on the balcony, you can view it projected onto a screen above the bar.  That way the House of Shields can get an ugly band and no one will care...because their images are all distorted on a white screen.
  
Its definitely a FiDi crowd comes here for happy hour, with the bike messengers apparently finding it to be a favorite too, and seeing as though I too am a FiDi worker...I imagine I will come here again.  Probably wont be as cozy sitting in a small booth with co-workers as it is with yelpers...i might actually stay standing, but I'll be back for an actual drink next time.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Last night, my coworker asked me to go with him to House of Shields for some beers after work. I didn't hate the place and they did have a good selection of beer on tap. But oh man, I was surprised when I got there.

I guess it's not just me who experienced the WORST bar tending service last night (Tuesday, 8/5/08). I thought the woman bartender just hated our group. My guy friend bought the first round. When he came to get a second round, he was completely ignored for 30+ mins. The bar wasn't too crowded and he made eye contact with her several times. She would serve other people who didn't even need a drink and completely ignored my friend. Eventually, he finally got the round. For the third round, he waited again...and waited...and waited. He tried going down to the other side of the bar, but he waited again...and waited...and waited.

He came back to our table discouraged. We joked about how he needed to show some skin to get better service. We wanted some beers, so I tried my hand at it. I went up to the bar and waited. She made eye contact with me. She served a few people that were before me and then ignored me for a while. Weird, but I can understand it. Eventually, I started to say something and she came up to me holding a stack of used glasses. One of them broke which she threw in the trash. A loud sound but nothing startling. The guy next to me, on the computer, didn't even seem phased. Instead of asking me what I wanted, she started flirting with the guy on the computer! "I didn't mean to startle you," she said as she continued smiling. She tried to continue the conversation, but he was more interested in his computer screen that what she was saying. Eventually, I said to her that I'd like to order 3 beers. 

She poured them. Then went to the other side of the bar and helped a group with about six drinks while ours waited by the tap. Then she helped another group with their drinks while our drinks were just sitting on the other counter waiting to be picked up. Eventually after serving two parties that came after me, she brought the drinks over. I told her to put it on my friend's tab and apparently, my friend noticed her give me a dirty look when I said that. 

Luckily for me, that was our last round. I can't deal with terrible service when it's unnecessary. I definitely would avoid this woman bartender (short brown hair and pale skin) if I came back. This place does have some memories for me - I always run into my friend I hardly see every time I come, which is almost never. By the way, the music alone was so bad that I wanted to line dance out of there. Yes, LINE DANCE. I think if someone wanted to go here, they'd have to drag me there and pay for all my drinks. Otherwise, no thanks. Minus one star from my original 3 star review.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
'Fi-Di'? WTF?  Why does everything in SF have to be defined by a 4 letter acronym these days?   

Anyway. I've been here many times and have always had a great experience...Bartenders are friendly and quick to serve (including the one that several of you are bitching about)

Reasons why the bartender was likely ignoring you, and pissed in general: 

- Happy hour 'Fi-Di' people may have a tendency to be demanding and shitty tippers. Large groups are the WORST.  Ordering fancy cocktails rather than sticking to beer, wine, and simple drinks (when a bar is crowded.. please don't ask them for a -tini cocktail or a margarita. Stick to the basics.) 

- Regular customers (who leave decent tips) are a bartender's bread and butter and they will always trump all other customers. They'll get drinks faster and get waited on first.  

- Perhaps someone in your group was snotty to her, and indicated that there would be a very small (or no) tip.  I waited tables and bartended for years.. and there's nothing more frustrating than a large, high maintenance group who makes it pretty clear right from the start that they're going to give you a shitty tip. 

-  And really.. if you leave zero tip on a 200.00 tab, expect to get cursed at, and possibly have something thrown in your direction.  

And yes. Maybe it's time for you to try a different bar.
author: I M.

description:
Something that was a wonderful piece of soul for this city, has been stripped clean. Remade in a new image that washed away a 100 years of history for one man's vision of a better future. 

That place, was a meeting house, a place where time had no meaning. A haven for the all walks of life to meet and and socialize and enjoy the company of down to earth people not concerned about the superficial. A place where day and night were no different and one could escape the hustle and bustle of the world outside in a house that shielded them from that very place.  

The new place, while pretty and clean, is now a shadow of the soul of San Francisco that it once was. It has been remade into another trendy bar and catering to a trendy and superficial crowd more concerned with image than content. Prices have gone up about 60% and the selection has gone down. 

It now feels artificial and plastic and like a new car attempting to be classic. The speakeasy feel has been wiped clean. Like Hollywood bastardizing a classic movie with another remake. Its been wiped of the spirit and much of the history that had been ingrained in the 100+ years that it has been in existence. 

Its too bright, the windows are open, velvet red curtains replaced by mini-blinds. I can see the world outside that a person would once come in to leave behind for a few wonderful hours in that once glorious hole.  Time no longer stands still inside. 

The crowd its currently attracting seems like a carbon copy of itself, people who would be seen at Rye or Absinthe. Not the mix of business men, bike messengers, service industry folks, art students, and tech geeks and people from all walks of life as it once was.

Its beautiful, but like an antique that has been restored, it has lost all of the value it once had in attempt to create a new charm. It no longer feels comfortable and like a place to relax, so much as a place to see and be seen, and to keep your guard up, and show how better you are than everyone else, instead of one that promoted relaxation. Its no longer inviting so much as egotistical and sterile feeling in presentation.

Perhaps in another 50 years it will regain the heart and the soul it once had and the old house will rise back up to its former glory. 

At least the giant urinal is still in the men's room. 

Until then, what I thought was the best bar in this city and representative of this city, is now just a carbon copy of every other new and trendy bar that has opened in the past few years attempting to be classic.
author: vintage o.

description:
I've never been a huge fan of this place but then again everytime I stop in for a drink I have a good time. Bartenders are a friendly bunch, my advice is go on the early side of happy hour when it's not too busy. 

The bar is a good place to enjoy your cocktails, but if you're with a small group, try and snag a booth. They go quick though.

I have never been here past 7:30pm, so wonder what becomes of it later in the night, or on weekends...
author: Nish N.

description:
I have gotten trashed here at least 5 times.  Two instances I barely remember and at some point I think I tried spinning...luckily it was a Wednesday at about 9pm and the 111 Minna crowd hadn't shown up yet.  

This place is Burning Man heavy...meaning that BM folks are all up in this place.   During the day and late afternoon it's courier central.  Chill environment...the bathroom is clean, the booths are comfy and it's a hop skip and a jump away from work.  You go here to drink...not to be seen.  Sometimes there's a DJ but not always.
author: Jay H.

description: A great throwback bar to the "Mad Men" Days  Lots of dark wood and ambience There is a small loft for private parties of which I attended one.  It's cool to hang up there and peer down on the world below.
author: Kevin P.

description:
