House of Shields is a bar.  It's a better bar than other bars cuz it's usually not that busy, it has cool dark red lighting, comfy seating and I've only ever been here with people I like.  They have good liquor and good beer and the prices are reasonable.

It's a worse bar than other bars because the tenders of the bar tend to ignore you and take forever to get anything done.  That's just how they are - it's one of those "if you don't like being ignored then go somewhere else" type of establishments.  c'est la vie.

For a chill, unassuming hang-out in SOMA though, House of Shields does the trick.
author: Oliver N.

description: Good beers on tap, great ambiance, nice bar tenders, clean bathroom.What else do you need?
author: Maryam M.

description:
I like this bar - it's smallish, unpretentious, and actually quite beautiful inside.  (Supposedly, it's a former speakeasy left more or less untouched from the Prohibition era.  A lot of places claim such historical significance, but in this case, it's a very credible assertion).

It draws mixed crowd - FiDi suits coming from work, art school kids from the Academy next door, bike messengers, party people on their way to the club - but don't let that deter you.  The 'tenders make stiff drinks, and they have live music - usu. funk/ jazz combos on Friday & Saturday nights - and/ or a DJ upstairs.  Check their site for the schedule: www.houseofshields.com/liveshow.htm

I sure would like to see what the below-ground Prohibition 'escape' tunnels (which supposedly lead to the Palace Hotel across the street) have to offer...

Party like it's 1921, mein...
author: Ryan W.

description:
Once I established myself with the bartenders, this places was golden! It was hard to get noticed at first, but I made it happen. Friendly place in SOMA about 1 block from Market street. I saw the whole mix of people in here, Yelp crew ready to get their drink on, FiDi peeps in suits, a backpacker traveling, the tattooed and pierced crowed, and hot tamales on the prowl. 

Drinks were bar priced, 5 bucks for Hef on tap- not too shabby. They have the comfy 2 person booth (that you can really fit 6 people in) and the half circle booth that you can get tons of people in. Lots of bar stools and an upstairs area (that remains a mystery since I didn't get a chance to go up). Their bar back called in sick, so I kept clearing the empty glasses on our 2 tables (we Yelpers can drink!). Someone else might - a star for this, but I didn't because the bartender gave me a few free drinks for helping her out! Score! :) 

I left a little bit drunk and a little bit confused... I saw people walk in with band equipment, I saw a table being set up, I even saw people that looked like they would be part of a band, but no one actually sang! It was the oddest thing! Did anyone else? Where did this band play? 

A good way to spend a Friday night!
author: Jessica R.

description: This place has lots of potential.  At 106 years of age, you have to show some respect.  The carved wood bar, dark interior, and fabulous lighting sets your frame of reference.  That said, the bartender was civil but not friendly; he seemed to not be happy to have to work this night.  Worse, he had his iPhone hooked up to the sound system to play harsh rap music over the sound system, which felt incongruous with the setting.  There were just a few patrons.  Overall, the place was not inviting.  After leaving, we walked past the Pied Piper bar at the Palace across the street - which appeared much warmer and welcoming.
author: Jeff J.

description: The House of Shield is a great after work drinking Bar. The remodeling on the place is outstanding and the Head Bartender Eric is great at making nice drinks.  If your in the Financial District, I will recommend trying the House of Shield for a cocktail
author: Brian S.

description:
This is one of the few bars walking distance from my work that I will actually still go to outside of Happy Hour. 

Its been around a long time, and it shows in the decor. I love the old dark wood, and the detail in the bar and ceiling. It is worth going here just to stare at the walls a while. 

House of Shields is not pretentious like so many of the bars near the FiDi, and it has a nice mixed crowd no matter what time of day or night you go. 

They could work on the drink specials a bit, they are few and far between, and the prices are not the best, but what they lack in wallet consideration they make up for in atmosphere.
author: Drue C.

description:
Good happy hour, easy going atmosphere and really tasty beers on tap like Hoegaarden.  

One of my friends (and by one of my friends I mean me...) even asked for more Vodka in her drink and the bartender happily obliged.  So come here and don't forget to ask for more alcohol in your drinks!
author: Katherine C.

description:
House of Shields I love you. Crappy bartender last night - not so much.

It's still a fabulous bar but when did it become acceptable to throw a glass at patrons?!

I saw all the comments on SFist. Team bartender and all that. Generally I side with employees but COME ON that's just too much.
author: Kerry H.

description: Despite what the reviews say, there was no happy hour. I went on a Wednesday at 5 pm. Am I missing something?
author: Caitlin B.

description:
friendly bartender, eclectic crowd, righteously poured drinks anchor steam beer.  i love the urinal behind the door in the men's room. it's impossible to use it and not get clocked in the head. a miracle of bad design or a great sense of humor? either way, it's a conversation starter.

love this place.
author: Brian B.

description:
This is your typical Fi-Di happy hour watering hole which means it's jam packed for a few hours after work, drinks are overpriced and it's really loud. Once the crowd thins out (around 8pm or so) it's actually pretty tolerable but by then it's time to move on to the next spot.

Man this is a boring review - I guess there's nothing either that great or that lame about the place to get my creative juices flowing. Sounds like three stars across the board.

ps...if you go, look up and check out the roof - it's pretty damn cool.
author: phil h.

description:
I've been here a lot, but never really had the time of my life.  In fact, it is way too loud in here.  I can't even hear the person standing next to me.  It is too dark for my taste.

I don't really like writing too much about a place if I don't have much to say, so I'll leave it at that.

Nice crowd, but too loud, and too dark.
author: Andrew G.

description: I adore this place and was happy to see that the renovation last year was not an overhaul - it's become a slightly cleaner and less shabby version of itself, with its charm intact.  While it can get REALLY loud during happy hour, the tall booths give me a sense of having some privacy.   The drinks are made stiffly enough, the prices are fair, and most of the bar staff is really attractive.  I only wish it was less crowded for happy hour - by the time my friends get off of work, this place is so packed that it's difficult to get a seat... or the bartender's attention.
author: Heidi M.

description:
It's just a bar that kind of looks like a bank, only it's a bar. There are no shields either.

But when you get there take a good look at the paneled wood ceiling and the mosaics in the tile on the floor. No points lost for decor.

However, the idea of using the upstairs area as a perfomance area is somewhat ill-concieved; the place is loud enough without having a group of young hellions making that infernal racket with their electified guitars and drum-sets. The space upstairs is too small to hold more than a 3 piece band and a dozen or so listeners; Some couches and tables for 4 or 5 would be a much better use of the space.

If I worked in the financial district, I'd probably be here after work a couple days a week, only not when a band is playing.
author: matthew r.

description:
Stumbled happily onto this funky little bar on the way back to the Montgomery BART. The mixed and lively clientele  (obviously some regulars, others just wandered in like me) makes it easy to park at the bar and eavesdrop or strike up a conversation. 

If you sit next to the right person and act interested, you'll learn that it was opened in 1908 and didn't allow women until well into the second half of the 20th century (he said 1970, but he was also a few scotches in...). Between the dark wood and the deep-set booths, this place has the ambiance that comes with aging gracefully.

House of Shields has the age and the oak-paneling to give the more austere Bourbon and Branch (a few blocks away) a run for it's money. Shields is a different beast though: a place to drop in on a whim or meet up before dinner, with a bartender who will happily make a Cosmo and stick around to chat.
author: Patrick T.

description: HoS is a great dark wood paneled bar that evokes the underground mystery of the Prohibition era. In fact, if you're nice, the bartender might even show you some of the secret passageways that still exist in this bar from that era. House of Shields has also become as of late, the defacto home to many web 2.0 events.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Now, now, now people. Let's not write off or trash one of the best bars in the city because of one crappy bartender and one crappy night. The fact that one bartender (working alone) went off the reservation doesn't mean this place sucks. 

In fact, they make the best damn very-slightly-dirty martinis in the city, the speakeasy atmosphere is awesome, they've got every beer I like, most of the bartenders are fantastic (especially Lexi, who I think is the owner, and whose charm tinged with just a hint of attitude is nothing short of magnetic), and it's super convenient to all things downtown. PS, if you want to check it out but can't handle the crowds (which can be significant) go in the rain, before 5, or on Saturday.
author: Emily E.

description: Dark, classic and not even smelly like you might expect an old pub to be. Plus, they care about how they pour a Guiness..build it that is!
author: Ted R.

description:
In my ongoing quest to find a neighborhood bar, House of Shields still has promise despite its problems.  They have a decent beer selection, decent enough manhattans and margaritas, and the dark woody atmosphere is a nice change of pace.

But!  From the bartender letting us order drinks only to take them *out of our hands* five minutes later and kick us out before 1 (along with a couple of other groups) because she apparently wanted to hang out with her friends, to the Friday / Saturday live music cover getting me down when I just want a place to chill, some scary rocking booths, and a crowd that sometimes makes me feel out of place or unwelcome, it's not always a place I want to spend a whole evening.  

And yet, I keep going back.
author: Bailey S.

description:
I truly believe that I should be allowed to write 2 reviews of this place. The first being this one...the sober trip to House of Shields, and of course the second being the next time I go and I get drunk. Anyway, here goes.

I was sober...drinking ice water and lemonade. Everyone else was drinking tasty refreshments, or at least I think they were. They smelled tasty.  I liked the bar...a little smaller than I expected it to be but it had a good atmosphere, and the non-Yelpers that were there seemed alright to me. I rarely venture all the way to the SOMA for a drink so this was quite an adventure for me. I guarantee if I hadn't been driving I would not have made it that far. I bet it would be great to get drunk here...I'll let you know next time.

Oh, snap, it took me like 15 minutes to get a glass of water, minus 1 star.
author: Laura D.

description:
Generally love this place, it is a BAR not a lounge, cafe or club.  Walking into the place feels as if you are walking into the 1930's.

On 08/05/08 there was a horrible bartendress working, I didn't see the glass thrown, we got out of there before that action happened.  But we did experience the just about the worst service ever.  2 beers and a campari with a twist, no need  for the bartendress to roll her eyes after our order, and it would have been nice for her to serve the beer to me the person that ordered it, and not the next group of people.   For those that defend that service, let her run your business and see how long you would stay in business.
author: Mickey D.

description:
I went here for a friends birthday gathering and thought it was a great little spot.  I feel like it is one of those places I have walked past a million times and have never even noticed it.

It was the regular dark dingy dive bar,  but still great!  The drinks were reasonably priced and extremely stiff, which I ALWAYS appreciate!  

My favorite thing was the old time ceiling and just the feeling that you were stepping back in time.  I've heard it is pretty busy during the week, but it was surely a great spot on the weekend to hang out for a birthday.

Definitely a great dive bar to check out!
author: Tressa C.

description:
It was TC50 (Techcrunch & startups) and I was invited out to a "Pitch Party" with a friend.  It beat the hell out of the other afterparties going on that night.

I randomly met a couple of stalkers.  Horray for [redacted] site making it even easier to.. 

It didn't look like much on the outside... and inside it was packed.  Little wooden booths lined the downstairs and the bar was green with envy as a myriad of characters edged their way toward the bar.

Free first rounds of beer.  Tech nerds, indies.... there were so many frames of glasses.

I met a few people who I knew off twitter.  It wasn't planned.  One was far shorter in person than I'd imagined.  Suddenly everything about him made a bit more sense.

We got our drinks and headed up to the actual party area.  It's just an open loft area overlooking the bar below.

Did I mention it was really packed?  I'm glad everyone used deodorant.... or at least I think they did.

The pitch party began as people came up to the mic & had 30 seconds to pitch their absolute worst startup idea.  They ranged from all across the board: from a dating site for ugly people (wait how is this different than most every other site? JK) to a place to rent a baby, to (the winner) a site devoted to giving carbon credits for successful emo kids committing suicide.

Prize was $50 and the booby prize was a jock strap signed by someone high on the food chain within the tech industry.

Drinks were moderately priced.  Atmosphere was very cozy.  All in all a great time was had by all.  Looking forward to coming out there again... maybe next Techcrunch?  See you there possibly maybe.
author: Jena S.

description:
Went to House of Shields for the first time last night and it was pretty empty on a Friday night. Would never have gone here, but I knew one of the bands that was going to play so I decided to check them out. "Dear Diary" rocks!

The place was dimmed and felt like a tavern out of nowhere. I did like the tall booths that we sat on and the giant video screen by the bar. The bathroom was fairly clean, but I wished they had a better lock for it and every time I was in there, I worried that someone was going to barge in.  Also, our shot of Kettle One Vodka got smaller and smaller towards the end of the night, even the glasses for cokes were shorter.  

As I sat with Pat G. and Padmae K. waiting for "Dear Diary" to go on, we watched this one woman spill her drink all over another woman's back.  The funny thing was that the woman did not even notice that she was soaking wet with beer. They were both so drunk that they just laughed about it and didn't care.  Another woman, who was still sober got some napkins to help wipe the beer off from her friend.  I looked at the woman who spilled the beer and I couldn't help but giggle too :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
I have only been to HOS on Monday nights, Heather is the bartender and hands down makes the best drinks, she makes it the way you want it, I also think she is a mind reader because even if you don't tell her the way you would like your drink she knows how you want it!!

Come Monday nights, its well worth it!!!!
author: T C.

description:
after much passive aggressive prodding i'm writing my first review for 2011.

they make good old man drinks, none of that "what's that?" when i ask for a sidecar. 

its not the most happening bar but its good for a date or something low key.
author: vanessa a.

description:
I'm not sure what transpired that caused a slew of "communications" people whose parents are lawyers to so viciously malign this place, but an isolated incident should not mar the reputation of House of Shields.

As far as an after-work place, this is the crossroads for fixie-riding hipsters and d-bag marina types. So, in a word, it's weird. The beer is good, the service is generally in line with a crowded place at happy hour. If you're lucky, you get a booth, or a barstool, but there's plenty of standing room too. 

On weekends, it's a much more chill environment, unless there is a band or dj, which is also super fun. The bartenders are, on the whole, very nice  people and HoS has a great selection of beers.

ETA: Also, it's one of the oldest bars in SF, and has a really cool environment. High, tin ceilings, and wood fixtures. It's a beautiful place.
author: Marisa J.

description: Took my boyfriend here cause I had been a couple times and I love the interior and feeling of this historic bar. We sat at the bar and our bartender, Patrick was fantastic. He was friendly and made awesome drinks. We were happy customers when we left, not to mention a tad buzzed.
author: Lynn C.

description:
OK Here's goes my first Yelp review... thanks to Amber K. for pushing me to do this.  

Since I'm on my first week in the City, I've been trying to hit up the various spots in SOMA, where I live.  Last night I was there at the HoS and found the atmosphere to be very laid-back and welcoming.  

Asides from the very cool all-wood bar/atmosphere that the previous reviewers have mentioned, I don't think I've seen a lineup of taps at any bar that got me as excited as this place.  Off the top of my head I remember that they have:  Boddington, Guinness, Fat Tire, Boont Amber, Strongbow, Lagunita IPA, Pabst Blue Ribbon (awesome off the tap, and $2 pints!), Camay, and many more tasty brews.  

Don't forget to try the $2 PBR pints!
author: Leo C.

description:
+ interior is dark and old fashioned
+ Franziskaner on tap
+ Close to my workplace
+ impossibly large urinal (I think it might be an upturned bathtub)
____________________________________________________

= 4 stars
author: joe b.

description:
I didn't expect this place would be pretty damn awesome since after all it's located in FiDi. I was afraid it would be filled with jocks and yuppies wannabes. 

The djs were playing britpop music and it was awe-some. Nan-cy and I were, specifically, having a good time. 

I think the price was pretty moderate. I couldn't really figure out how much was each but SoCo+Coke and Margaritta= $13, and SoCo+Coke and IPA= $10. 

The only downside hey cute bartender, could you put more SoCo in my drink than Coke?
author: Perry S.

description:
They kind of charge way too much for beer here. But they have huge, comfy booths you can lose yourself in. We had a boisterous group there last night and some awesome friendly employees of the art school across the street offered to share their booth so we made some new friends! The men's urinals are apparently one of the largest ever, we had to take some footage of it, much to the non-amusement of TK. I'm no expert on urinals, but I didn't see anything to get all worked up over.
I believe they have some live music upstairs, we were having a nice time chatting when all of a sudden someone began a deafening interlude. We had to bounce so we could continue talking. Makes you wonder what they're aim is with this bar.
author: Colleen B.

description: We saw the sign for this bar from the palace hotel across the street. I thought the name sounded cool so we went and checked it out. Walking inside was like going back in time. No tvs, and the music was great. Best of all the bartenders were friendly and welcoming. Patrick is easily one of the best bartender experiences ive had at a bar. Very knowledgeable and takes pride in his craft. If i was a native of the city this would be my backyard hangout.
author: Brad L.

description: I"m not sure when they remodeled this place, but our work team went there afterwork last night and it was a really nice place to unwind. The wood interior is beautiful, as is the bar. The selection of draft beer isn't large (about 5) but the range and quality is good. The crowd was friendly and the bartender was quick. What else do you need for a post-work tipple?
author: William R.

description: The Saturday night I came with a group of friends, the place was surprisingly boring. For being what seemed like a slow Saturday, it took quite some time for the bartender to acknowledge me. I ordered a cocktail, which was bland, uninspired and lacked creativity. In retrospect, I realize I should have just ordered a beer.
author: Kadie C.

description:
One of the strangest places I have ever seen a show (that is an official place to see a show, rather than an impromptu performance at say the mall).  Bands play upstairs in a teeny tiny room that fits one table with about 3 seats and standing room for 10 more.  If you can't squeeze your way upstairs, the shows are "broadcast" on a screen over the bar. It was like seeing a show in someone's very small attic.

The bar itself has a very laid back vibe. No pushy bartenders. Pretty good selection of beer including Chimay. I even got a good size beer back with my whiskey.  Overall, if it wasn't for the location (a bit out of my way) I would probably come here more often.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Bartender here was a complete jerk. Apparently ordering a non-alcoholic drink warrants walking away before taking the order and replying with a snide comment. Won't be returning to this dime a dozen bar with delusions of grandeur!
author: D. S.

description:
I had passed House of Shields dozens of times before ever venturing inside. I prefer bars to clubs, but I've been working too late to go to happy hours downtown. Last Friday, a friend decided she needed a drink, and I decided I needed a break.

We ended up here by accident; the rain forced us into somewhere close, and you can see the sign outside from a half a block away. It definitely has a pub-like feel, with dark wood and booths. It's much smaller than the Bank of Ireland, and it wasn't too crowded on a Friday night. We were able to get seats at the bar right away.

The blustery weather suggested that whiskey was the way to go, and HOS serves Powers Irish Whiskey. Most bars in the City (and everywhere) stock Jamesons and Bushmills. They're sort of the Coke and Pepsi of Irish whiskeys (provided that drinking a Coke let everyone know you're Catholic). I guess that makes Powers the RC Cola of whiskey. Anyway, they have the whiskey I like, so I'm adding a star for that.

Our bartender took our order straightaway. My friend was feeling rather frisky, and decided to steal olives out of the condiment holders behind the bar. This pretty much destroyed the bartender-patron relationship. When she was unable to make my friend a proper sidecar (which from reading the reviews is an apparent problem), we decided to head elsewhere.

This place has potential, or maybe its best days are behind it. Certainly, if you're going to be an old-school bar, you need to have bartenders that can make traditional cocktails. It's worth a visit, despite its flaws (unless you're a sidecar drinker).
author: Timothy O.

description:
I LOVE the red chandeliers.  Was lucky enough to find a tiny booth to house a great conversation.  Good drinks.  Better company.  And I like that its friendly and unpretentious.

It was hard to walk away though.  By the time we had finished our [one] drink each, the whole bar was eye-ing our booth.  We reluctantly handed it over...
author: Neha S.

description: I go here for the central location & general ambiance of the place. Beautiful interior always feels welcome & very familiar.  The Happy Hour is when you should come, good prices for an otherwise typical FiDi locale. It can sometimes be difficult to find a seat during Happy Hour, but that's typical of any place that is any fun. It's easy to get my friend's to come here because its downtown & less than a block away from BART.
author: Lily R.

description:
A small dive bar with lots of charm. There is one big booth in the back that seats about 8. If your party is bigger, expect people to be standing around the booth. When I first got there, the back area smelled kinda like urine. Guess I know where the bathrooms are located.

The drinks had good balance - good flavor and kick. The atmosphere is not pretentious. No super loud music during happy hour. Just good conversation and friends. A worthy place to go.
author: Judy L.

description: They re-opened, it's even classier than before and there's no more cover on Friday/Saturday! YESSSSSS
author: Tom M.

description:
This is definitely my kind of dive -- old-timey, dingey & perfect for hovering over tonics, elixirs & spirits. It could very well be used as the set for a new show on FX entitled "'Cheers' in Hell". Grabbing a drink at House fo Sheilds is every bit as enjoyable, though the conversation is quite a bit more acrid, it's darker & more sinister, & nobody will ever know your name, or be glad you came. 

If I had to make up the perfect fake history of House of Shields, I'd tell people that it was originally owned by a famous but much maligned master illusionist who one day mysteriously & inexplicably vanished (naturally). 

There is an aire of mischief within, & its booths are perfectly sized for small parties of schemers. 

Long-talied coats, top hats, & devilish goatees are optional, of course.
author: Pete J.

description:
Sorry House of Shields but I guess you missed the memo about people preferring music to accompany their cocktails. What can I say, a bar with no music = bummer!. 

Maybe I went on an off night but the service was slow, the bar desperately needed to be cleared and there was seriously no music. Aside from that the inside of the bar is very cool looking. Not too big, booths along the wall, and long bar. There is even a small upstairs area where a DJ can set up and people can gather. The drinks were standard and I would gladly try House of Shields again and hope for a better experience.
author: Theresa T.

description: This is a good happy hour joint. Not quite divey and not quite Irish pubby. It's fun, spacious, great drink specials, a little fratty - but not anti-hipster. Dark, loud, but not so loud that you can't have a conversation.
author: Andrew K.

description: Dennis Leary is one cool mofo and I knew he would do this place justice.  And when I walked in I realized pretty much nothing had changed from back in the day. The prices are reasonable and there are no mixologists makin'  bougie drinks.  It's just a bar.
author: Roger H.

description:
I come here about once a week after a long day at work and after two or three Bullitt Bourbons I feel sufficiently 19th century to go on with my evening.  

The House of Shields sits on a fortunate part of New Montgomery, across from the storied Palace Hotel.  It's the stuff of Herb Caen yarns and Dashell Hammett tales.  It evokes a sense of horse-and-carriage era San Francisco.  

Music some nights, live bands on others.  Friendly, no-nonsense bartenders.  Coversations waiting to happen.
author: Ryan P.

description: The beer selection isn't huge, but they have a full bar and take cards. This is increasingly becoming rarer and rarer in this city, so that's a plus. The prices are a little high but it's the Financial District. If this place wasn't right next to my work, I probably wouldn't go here. That's not to say it's bad, just not entirely my style. The decor is nice, the atmosphere is laid back, but you pay for it.
author: Alfredo A.

description: Decent scotch selection and some out of the way Bourbons I had never tried.  Major points earned by the single ice cube for my single malt.  Good crowd and a historic place as told to me by patrons at the bar.
author: J G.

description: Came back here around midnight on a Thursday and it was a lot more fun when it wasn't so crowded/I was able to get a seat. Pretty standard bar otherwise. Friendly waitstaff.
author: Melody L.

description:
How could I have forgotten to yelp you? 
I've been here quite a few times in the past few months, always a pleasure, thank you, thank you very much. No, really, you're too kind. 
Great happy hour, but get there early bc seating is scarce...unless you're the cool kids who get to go upstairs. 

It's a great place to start or end the night. They just make it so comfortable for you to get great service and refills...it's all part of a master plan. 

I once saw a girl in a cell phone outfit sitting at a booth. Nothing was going to stop her from enjoying the Shield. Not even the brusk, cold shoulder of a burly bike messenger.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Cool bar area, cool upstairs area.  And they used to have a shoegazer night.  

Why oh why did shoegazer nite have to go??????
author: Anne-Marie R.

description:
I'm surprised House of Shields is open everyday except Sundays... 

$2 PBRs
$4 Fat Tires on tap
$5 AMFs (not sure if this was full price, though)
Bartenders, or rather bartender was friendly, nice, and attentive
On a weekday, don't be surprised to only see one bartender
On Saturday, I believe there can be as many as two
Single person bathrooms
High ceilings
Dim lights, soooo everyone looks better
Chill music (Tuesday night: I felt like I was hanging out on a wooden porch sippin' on some Jeremiah Weed Sweet Tea. Wednesday night: Some upbeat hip hop stuff.
Many booths
Classic bar with big mirrors behind it
Lots of locals

As long as I continue working in the close proximity of this bar, I am gonna continue coming here after work.
author: Maggie H.

description:
I dig this place. Location is a little tough, but I love the little booths and the strong ass drinks. It looks like something straight out of the 30's. And I think it actually is!
Extra points for letting my friends film there after closing.
author: Owen T.

description:
I came here for happy hour with 6 other people from work last week.  I love the location as it's almost across the street from my office.  We got there around 5:45pm and were able to score a nice table that seated all of us.

It is pretty dimly lit inside so if you come here when it's still light out, your eyes will need to do some adjusting.  There is another level, which I think is a balcony.  Unfortunately I didn't make it up there, but maybe next time.

For drinks, all the guys had beer, and us girls had cocktails - Grey Goose and tonic or Grey Goose and soda, which were good.  Not too hard to mess up any of our drinks though.  I definitely would not come here for a glass of wine though because they don't have much of a selection.  But it's not a wine bar so you shouldn't expect a stellar wine list.
author: Cathy M.

description:
I can't believe I've never reviewed this place.  This is my favorite bar in the city.  It's about a block from work, it's all dark and mellow and it's usually got a really nice crowd.  I mostly swing through there at the beginning of the week when it's less crowded, but I'll venture there on Thursdays and Fridays too.  

The bartenders pour a mean drink and have fantastic attitudes to match.  I always feel welcome and well cared for.  And I ALWAYS leave much drunker than when I showed up.  Big huge bowl-sized Bulleit Manhattans always seem to cheer me up.
author: Jessica B.

description: I have a certain fondness for the House of Shields as it was the first place I ever got trashed on tequila shots.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Stop 4 on Trial Run BART Crawl: Montgomery Station / House of Shields

We had originally planned to hit Maxfield's Pied Piper Bar across the way on New Montgomery, but we were honestly too ready for a drink to wade through hotel doormen and the like.  We saw the neon glow of House of Shields and poked ourselves in for the portion of the evening where "buzzed" became "fuggggin drunk".

The Good: As one of my cohorts pointed out, "this is very San Francisco".  The crowd was definitely local, the vibe was amazingly chill, and the bartenders took great care of us.  We sidled up the the bar and drank until the boozetalk was flowing from our mouths like Hoover Damn on a "bust it loose" day.

The Bad: At some point, the bartenders started hurling plastic pitchers at some people sitting at a booth to our right.  Honestly we were too drunk to care much, but it was still enough to be annoying and slightly worrying... Maybe the glass pitchers were reserved for our loud asses??

The Ugly: For some reason, one of my lot was passed out just short of making it to the women's restroom.  I think she didn't have enough force to get into the door, assumed someone was taking some serious time off inside, and just fell asleep on the steps.
author: Brett L.

description:
The live jazz and the very generous bartender make this place awesome; I was buzzin a lot faster than any other place in SF.

This is a really cool place for happy hour.
author: Brian L.

description: Great drinks, small location but a great place for happy hour since it is about a block from our work
author: madi b.

description:
Went here after a rough workout to meet some people.

Great location, off of market in the financial district.  
Bar tender was friendly and the drinks were reasonable.
Had Gimlet and Moscow Mule. 

Gimlet not impressive.

Must try: Moscow Mule!
author: Jac J.

description: Old school drink mixers, great martini!!!
author: Aaron R.

description:
This is one of the few best places in the city where you can throw back a couple vodka tonic drinks or two.  It's an unexpected surprise in an unexpected district.

It's a laid back pub complete with old-world style booths, dark and dim, with pale faces peeking through.  A throwback to European establishments where the crowd is always easy and the music selection impeccable.  They used to have a great shoegaze, post-punk, psychedelia night on Fridays and I'm not sure if it's still around.  But no fear, if you drop-in after work on a weekday you'll be sure to find the perfect song to match those faded memories.
author: Hellyn M.

description:
It's long overdue but I had to give an update!

Cheap drinks + great management = the perfect makeup happyhour. :)
author: Sapana S.

description:
Maybe I've just gone to this place at the wrong times but I always feel like there are better places to go in this neighborhood. The best parts about this bar are that it's near work and that they have a good selection of alcohol.

For me the downsides to this place are that the decor is super dreary, I always get the sense that I'm having a pint in an old barn and that the lighting is so dark it doesn't make me feel energetic.

My suggestion to the owners is to redecorate...
author: Bryan B.

description:
Tonight I met a friend from Oakland for a drink City-side, and she wanted to introduce me to the House of Shields. So introduce she did.

Upon walking in, we encountered several bicycles -- and bicycle messengers saddled up at the bar. Rule of thumb: If bicycle messengers frequent a bar, chances are good that it's a good place -- and that the bartenders are good people. So the first impression was solid.

Given the history of the place -- and the fact that I'm a history geek -- I was intrigued by the bar's long run, the large urinal in the bathroom, the original tile work on the floor, and the lore of the tunnels beneath. Usually when I'm in San Francisco, I hang out at the Buddha Bar in Chinatown (which, if http://www.yelp.com/biz/51gscyjxkVari5gK3qIsTA is any indication, has changed immensely since I used to frequent the joint; what happened to the aging woman tending bar? The Chinese soap operas on the TV? The scarcity of non-Chinese?) -- and it, too, is rumored to have tunnels underground. Like bike messengers, tunnels beneath bars are a good thing.

We took a two-top on the side, and I ordered an Anchor Steam and a sparkling water with lemon. Total? $4 plus tip. Nice. While we hung out for two hours catching up and hanging out, the messengers left, more people came in -- claiming the larger booth beneath the loft-stage area -- and the volume increased, largely because some idlers at the bar got progressively drinky and thinky. But the place never got packed. Nish, you might enjoy it after 7:30 on a weekday.

The place is a little too clean for me -- and the ceilings perhaps a little too high (although there are indications that there used to be a suspended ceiling; I honestly can't picture that) -- for it to sing frequency to me, but I can see the House of Shields as a pleasant occasional watering hole. (It's also in a weird neighborhood for a solid local; in fact, it feels like a local waiting to happen.)

Kudos to all involved.
author: Heath R.

description: I've been trying to call them for a week now, Everyday, during their business hours and no one is picking up the phone.
author: idan b.

description:
If you can find a place to sit, I really like this place.  It's shocking how dark it is inside and whenever I come back outside I forget that it's still day light out. 

It's my quick after work drink/meet people spot.
author: Jessica T.

description:
if you want  a taste of faux san francisco and are staying at the palace hotel-  HOS is your spot.

It's unassuming, they mix a strong drink; however, bring your nost plugs because the place smells of dirty biker pits.

I give an additional star because they had excellent drink specials.
author: Brooke M.

description: I love this place! The atmosphere is great and the bartenders are fun! They actually know how to make a good Gibson, and a proper one at that! Be prepared though, the drink arent cheap!
author: Brent C.

description:
Dive bar!  

Decent place if you could get a booth, otherwise, it's so so.  Good place for a quick drink or two with your friends before you head to bart or market st.

Don't expect to meet your significant other here...*lol*
author: Jeff H.

description:
Two reasons I will never go back there (the short):

1.  Encountered a staff that seemed put out by telling them there were feces all over their bathroom.

2.  Didn't tell me they put Jalapeno olives in my drink, and just served it up.

The long (and what I really didn't like was the attitude):

Ordered a Martini with three olives.  Took a drink.  Okay.  Took a bite - Jalapeno olives!  I don't mind spicy, just in the right spot.  Asked bartender for regular olives, was told they didn't have any.  Didn't bother to ask me if I would like a new drink.

REALLY? - you just take it upon yourself to put those in my drink.  I would call it a rookie mistake, but I don't want to offend a rookie.

Took the jalapeno's out of the olives, but the drink was burned. Tried to do another swig, but just couldn't do it, and was frankly a little annoyed.  I politely apologized, but said I just couldn't do it.  The bartender took my drink and poured me a new one right at the same level that I was at when I handed over my last, as if I was just trying to get 4 free swigs of a drink.  Strike one.

Went to the bathroom, opened the door and was bombarded with the smell of feces.  They were EVERYWHERE!  Told that same bartender that "your bathroom is in need of attention, someone smeared the walls."  Again, it was like I had the nerve to ask for regular olives.
author: Calvin H.

description:
I love this bar.  It used to be the official bar of the Palace Hotel, before they added their own bar.  And it is one of the oldest bars in San Francisco.  The dark wood bar is impressive and beautiful, and probably totally wasted on people who stop here just for a happy hour drink.

The owners are all really nice, and I like coming in here and mixing it up with the locals.  I like the bartenders here!
author: Julie B.

description:
While pencil-neck historians insist on myocardial infarction, and conspiracy nuts claim murderous maladjusted spouses, every San Franciscan knows President Warren G. Harding died in the House of Shields. His addiction to pussy and alcohol is tantamount to his signing of the Treaty of Versailles, and on a warm night in August 1923, the booze finally did him in. His wingmen found him upstairs, face down dead, surrounded by panicked prostitutes. Public knowledge of his rather shameful demise was of course out of the question (it is not statesmanlike to drink oneself to death during Prohibition while fucking hookers), so his two brave associates carried him through the tunnel which connects the House of Shields to the Palace Hotel under New Montgomery St. and escorted the corpse back to his room, claiming fatigue from his recent train trip from Seattle. I imagine this as the Jazz Age version of Weekend at Bernie's.

Eager to verify this tale, my colleague and I performed a quiet search for the tunnel, and I can confirm its existence. However, the exit point is behind the front desk at the Palace Hotel, and unless you can think on your feet faster than I can, I advise you come up with a reason for being there before starting your subterranean journey (look for my one-star review of the Palace Hotel's security staff in the coming months [hi, Gary!]) I don't want to ruin the adventure by telling you where the tunnel begins, but your first step will be in the ladies' room.

This bar must be saved, if purely for historical reasons. It is a national monument. Also, the girl who bartends on Monday night is one of my favorites. Please don't tell her about my underground archeological expedition, she'll kick me out.
author: trevor c.

description: Classic fireman's watering hole, bites the dust. Damn, I'm pissed.
author: Y S.

description:
Basically the unofficial "Academy of Art University Bar". Great place to go after evening and night classes, especially during the week when the crowds are minimal. Friday and Saturday nights can be hard to find room to sit, or sometimes even stand (as is the case for most bars in the city on weekend nights). 

But the atmoshphere and architechture are great to be in and around. The location is super convenient; makes it easy to meet for drinks after work as well as class or just for the hell of meeting friends. 

The live music upstairs is usually a bad idea, since the place is so small and the bands are usually too loud and too crappy; makes for an unpleasant drinking night.
author: Stu C.

description:
I work around the corner and like the HOS for the convenience but the male bartender was so rude. One of my co-workers, I guess, took too long to give her order and he said, "What do you want, I have other people to wait on" - the place was not even crowded.

The second time I went to the bar he rudely said, "Whaddya want?".

There are other bars with better specials and friendlier service. I don't recommend the HOS if you have other options.
author: Kevin K.

description: Great old school bar. Classy but not stuck up at all. Super knowledgeable bartenders. Recommended a great bourbon and when you have a drink over a rock, it's just one BIG square ice cube. It's cool. And he had a drink of the same bourbon with me in his personal shot glass that he keeps in his front vest pocket, which was also cool. He made a drink called an Aviation that looked great and that I'll definitely try soon.
author: Jason K.

description:
I walked into this place and really enjoyed the decor. Very 1900's elegant saloon kinda thing. I was waiting for men with top hats and monocles to come in asking for a mint julep. Though if that were the case, I don't think I would have been allowed in, I might as well have rolled up in a rickshaw with overly exaggerated slanted eyes with my queue and my robe pawning mushu on a trip out of Chinatown.

I've just been here once, but I'd for sure come back for a relaxed beer with a couple of friends.... that is if I can find my queue.
author: Rocky K.

description: This place is conveniently located outside of the Montgomery Street BART station.  It'd be a much cooler place if a) there was more seating to accommodate the after work and other crowd b) there were seats on the balcony too.  The drinks were reasonably priced considering it is in the FiDi.  I only ran into a few Yelpers but I'm pretty sure most arrived early enough for happy hour or came much later.  Our growling stomachs took over our need for alcohol (or my lack of need for it anyway).  I'd probably go back here and grab a booth right away.  It seems like it'd be a nice place to sit with friends.
author: Amy J.

description: Conveniently located by the Montgomery BART station. I've come in here a few times for drinks. Nothing spectacular but a cool place for drinks and a little chit-chat with friends.
author: Joan S.

description: A great place to HH on a Monday afternoon...you can have a stiff, no nonsense Sidecar here made with local brandy and lounge with hipsters and oldsters alike. Shanti, the Monday night bartender is super-cool and seems to be the kind of guy you can talk to about life's problems. The interior is well placed back together, there is a balcony upstairs for about 25 people with its own bar for private parties. Every hour is happy hour...about $30 for three drinks (Scotch, Margarita and Sidecar).
author: Sarah M.

description: Bar is ok.  I like the work they did with the back bar and the beautiful light fixtures that surround the room.  Would I hang out here all the time?  Probally not.  It iwas nice to check it out and have a cocktail.  Manhattan's were really good.  Sidecars - sucked.
author: Doreen D.

description:
"Hey let's go to House of Shields". I used to hear this a lot when I worked down the street from HOS. I always have the same reaction to this invitation - "House of Shields? Really? Again"?

This bar is by no means terrible, but it's just a bar that's a little on the dive-bar side. No biggy. They do have cheap PBR which I know was the draw for my friend EB and I will say that you are not likely to see many suits here - no wayward Marina kids. That's kind of nice.
author: J F.

description: I thought this was a great place.  Has a bit of the by-gone-era SF feel to it.  I was told there was even an underground prohibition-era tunnel connected to it.  Has a decent beer selection and a small upstairs area.  Wasn't too crowded on a Wednesday.
author: Mike S.

description:
Boring, boring, boring. Showed up here on Wednesday night, the place is empty and cold. Cold as in the outside temperature is in the 40's and they can't be arsed turning the heating on and they left the front door open.

So, we sat there in scarves and sucked down the PBRs for $2 (that got them an extra star) and tried not to watch the couple making out at the bar at 7pm on a Wednesday night. Except they were right in front of us, and felt a PDA every 30 seconds was necessary. House of Shields? more like House of Suck!
author: Joseph T.

description:
Thanks for keeping my teeth floating before, during and after class.

P.s. wicked awesome job with my Black velvet
author: Dani M.

description:
Unpretentious.
Loud music.
$2 PBRs
$5 Drinks.
Casual.
Live music.

Loud loud music.... loved the music but at the same time a bunch of 30 somethings in a loud bar is not the prettiest picture. Needless to say some of us had lost our voices the next day.
author: Pooja S.

description:
One of my favs for happy hour.  Good mix of geeks, bike messengers, and other working peeps. Bartenders are friendly enough.  

Its a dive bar though, so if you find your standards are too high for this joint, the palace hotel is across the street.
author: Ashley P.

description:
This place has personality to it... I was there early on so i didn't get to see the band or anything but I think it looks good.

It makes me feel like it's a place out of the 1800s, even though the people are not stuck up and the music is up to date.  It's probably somewhere I would go after work, not on a Saturday.
author: Cassio P.

description:
First impression after I walked in alone to meet friends was this place definately seemed like a local favorite.  Most of the people sitting at the bar knew the bartender and were all making conversation.

The bartender was so freaking friendly.  Probably one of the friendlist bartenders I've ever encountered in the city of San Francisco.  She was witty and very considerate.

The bar has a sort of pub feel to it.  Old wood bar and tables with the typical smell that old wood gets when it's been marinating in beer for who knows how long.

It's dark and comforting place to relax after work, I had a great time with the friends I met here.  I would go back for sure.
author: Mary R.

description:
I like this bar a lot. I like that it seems 'old as dirt'. The tiny booths are great and the bartenders are pleasant and attentive.

I especially love and appreciate that their toilets have half flushes. This is something I've only seen in the South Pacific, New Zealand to be specific. Something this whole country could benefit from.
author: alexa c.

description:
This is a great place drink. It is a classy place that puts most bars to shame. The intricately detailed wooden punctuations and mosaic floors set the mood in this timeless establishment. On a good day you can hit some great live music, on other days, its just loud. 
It's location makes it a great place to gather your friends prior to kicking off a grande evening after a long work week.
author: Travis W.

description:
They've got Chimay = big plus. 
They've also got nowhere to sit = no bueno. 

Worth a stop if you're only grabbing a quick drink. Otherwise, tons of other options. 2.5.
author: Jory M.

description:
Back when men waxed their mustaches and bars had fancy light fixtures, there was the house of shields. This is one of those "Built in 1905 the bar blah, blah, blah..." bars and it still retains that kind of classy feeling. The interior is all wood and typically quite dark inside. It kinda has that classic speak easy vibe going for it. The kind of place you want to order an old fashioned or a sidecar. 

To mix with the classic bar thing, on some nights they have live music upstairs on this little half floor overlooking the bar. Nice bar to pop into if you're looking for a mix of music and martinis. 

Bonus feature! Guys. You got to use the can here. They have this urinal that is freaking huge. Seriously, if you're not careful you could fall into it and get lost. Guess they just don't make 'em like that anymore.
author: Andy A.

description:
If you want to hang with cool bike messengers after work, this is the dive bar for you!

As other people have mentioned, it's extremely dark inside, which makes for a sort of brooding atmosphere. Despite this, the bartenders are friendly and get the job done (although depending on the crowds, it can take quite a while to get a drink). The seating downstairs is sparse, with just a few booths around the edge (great for squeezing six or so pals together all cozy like). The whole experience is just completely unpretentious.

I like it.
author: Ava S.

description:
I used to work just down the street and my co-workers would drag me here at least once a week.

Lots of bike messengers, live music every once in a while, the bartenders are pretty cool, (I know that they used to do shots and give my buddies free drinks, though I never experienced it).

The decor reminds me of a haunted house. Weird lamps above the booths, I think they were little mini statues though I might be wrong. For some reason I remember there being cobwebs hanging from the ceiling as well. I used to not want to go here because I thought it seemed creepy.

However, Hos grew on me and it's a good place to hang out after work. They do indeed have big ole booths for your sitting pleasure.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
It is a beautiful bar, with solid drinks. I like to get there in between the after-work and the DJ crowd. 

It also never hurts to ask if they have any pickled eggs - trust me. 

Another plus, it is located within stumbling distance from BART.
author: Julia P.

description:
My favorite happy hour spot. 

It can be too crowded at times. Not a whole lot of seating, and half the booths are lumpy and uneven. 

One bartender is horribly slow, but the rest are up to par. 

Prices run about average for the city. I pay $8 for a lemondrop. 

Half the clientle I recognize from other dive bars around the city. The rest seem like hapless business types looking to get dirty. 

Definitely not a good spot for a group bigger than 3 or 4. Perfect for a bitch-fest party of 2.
author: Towanda S.

description: Nice, cozy, old school, classy place. Boddington's, Trumer Pils, and Chimay on tap is always nice to see.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
1. $2 PBRs
2. The coolest (and largest) urinal in town
3. High-backed booths perfect for a secret rendezvous
4. Did I mention $2 PBRs?

Really, there's no good reason not to come to HOS. The beer is cheap, the crowd is diverse (from bike messengers to business suits), and the service is top-notch.
author: Billy L.

description:
I don't have much to say, except one thing:

The urinal in the mens room is the BIGGEST F-ING URINAL IN THE HISTORY OF MANKIND!
author: Trevor J.

description:
I just don't understand people.  I mean how can you not give this place 5 stars?  Not only does it have $2 PBR on tap and they let you bring in your own food, but they also have a full stock of condiments (i.e Sriracha) what's not to love about that?

It can get a little crowded but the bar seems to magically clear out at 7pm every night, which is exactly when I tend to roll in.  This place also has live music from time to time.  It's always mellow and relaxing, never distracting.  This is my new favorite drinkery, and baring any drastic changes to this it'll be a favorite for years to come.

My only real beef is that
author: Aaron S.

description: Solid SOMA location to hang out and meet friends after work before heading home on Muni or Bart -- about a block off of Market.  Can get kind of packed, but the small booths still provide for intimate conversation.
author: Andy B.

description: After 5 years in SF, I finally checked this place out. they have CHEAP PBR on draft! and the decor was exquisite. I just couldn't stop looking at the ceiling. Overall it was fairly crowded, but I still enjoyed myself. The waitstaff was friendly too, that's always a plus in my book.
author: Amber K.

description:
Statuesque blonde serving beer and whiskey.  What could be better - except that she is super awesome cool.  That's enough for 4 stars, but when I told her my entire team had been laid off, she gave us a beer on the house - (rock on!) - 5 stars.  
Beware - if you bedazzle her with your t-shirt, she might get confused...  Order with caution...
author: Mark F.

description: Typical Fi-Di Bar. Decent bartenders and decent place to chillax after work. Kind of dark and gothic, but not divey. The dark and candles make everyone look better so its all good. They have $2 PBR specials during happy hour.
author: Amy S.

description:
wtf? seriously.

so i came across some reviews and a story. 

group comes for a night out celebrating. 

the bar is crowded, they cant get drinks as fast as theyd like, yet they stick around and drink here. 

they leave ZERO TIP on a $200 bill. 

the bartender throws a glass on the floor and kicks them out. 

ok, looky here, i am what you might consider a professional drinker. ive drank everywhere in sf and ive dealt with all types behind the bar. NEVER IN MY LIFE HAVE I LEFT ZERO TIP. i HAVE ordered drinks and after getting HORRIBLE service, left, but i AT LEAST TIPPED THEM A BUCK FOR TRYING, and for getting me a drink. 

if their service is bad, LEAVE. dont continue to order drinks and then tell the server after a few rounds, since you gave me bad service i left you zero tip. 

ive been here several times. a couple times, it took longer then i wanted to wait for drinks so i went elsewhere. simple.  it was crowded, there were only two ladies behind the bar. there were 30 or so people trying to order drinks at once. its pretty simple.

seriously, do some people feel so entitled that every server they encounter must stop everything to wait on them?

my original rating wouldve been 3 maybe 3.5, but definately rounded up for the unlucky bartender that experienced this shitty night and handled it just fine.

a broken glass? you damn lucky it wasnt me getting you drinks. a broken glass would be the LEAST of your worries.
author: Euge L.

description:
I was a bad, bad girl last weekend and it all started at House of Shields. Which is not surprising, since I've spent many a night imbibing at this behemoth of a bar. I quite like House of Shields. Friends used to throw parties here and a lot of folks from my office would head here to get our drank on after hours. Business hours, that is. 
The crowd is surprisingly cool considering the location, there is ample room for large parties (large, obnoxious parties), and there are all kinds of nooks and crannies to misbehave in (if you're discrete like that. I am not.). 
The trouble is this: The bartenders (on our last trip, at least) blew chunks. Like really. They BLEW. At one point, one of them had been talking to (showing her boobs to) a guy for about 5 minutes to the exclusion of everyone waiting for a drink. This is one BIG bar. There are lots of thirsty people. Lisa and I finally asked the dude she was desperately showing her tits to if HE would buy us a drink, since she didn't seem concerned with helping US. He agreed. This is how we got our drinks. Oh, please...Then it happened again when I went back for another round. Except this time, it was another dude and she was flipping her hair around like she was posessed.  It was really annoying. And sad.
HOS is a great place for large groups and there are usually plenty of cute boys with which to occupy one's self. If you're a girl, chances are good you'll get plenty of free drinks. Bathrooms are huge but there's usually a line as the night wears on. I'll be back. Again and again. Because it's centrally located and a good place for happy hour. But, please! Someone get those bartenders an ounce of self respect already!
author: Autumn K.

description: bit rustic...bit dive...bit dark....bit mellow....it's a "saloon" in the fidi.....tired of packed happy hour bars?...tired of standing?....house of shields provides a bit mellow atmosphere with ample booth seating.......$3 beer special
author: Hen A.

description:
I picked up my brother from the airport who had just got in from Hawaii and was staying at the palace  hotel.  We stepped across the street to have a quick pint at this joint, and regretted it 10 fold.  The bartender was a total jerk, ignored us for the first 10 minutes, finally took our order, which we made a slight mistake on.  (ordered a bud light for my brother, but he wanted something else)  Bartender insisted too bad for us, and we had to pay anyway and stay and drink in discomfort.  He asked us if we had a problem with that and we said yes, and we left.  It was dark, noisy and the service was terrible.  Do we really have to deal with stuff like that in this city?  we would have tipped him 3 xs the amount of the beer.  

grrrrrrrrrrrr....
author: Matt V.

description: I had walked by this place about a hundred times without going in.   From the outside I kept thinking that it was a place for the men who wear suits and the women who follow them around, which kept me away.  Surprisingly it is nothing of the sort.   It has a very diverse and relatively inclusive crowd.  Even better, it has Chimay and Hoegaarden (though the bartendress thinks it's pronounced HO-garden) on tap.
author: Beau G.

description: Stopped by here for an evening drink since we were staying nearby at the Marriott.  The music is super loud here, but I liked the high ceilings and cozy little booths tucked into the windows.  While they had some decent beers on tap this place seems to be all about their mix drinks.  All in all, we had a good time catching up with our friend from San Fran here.
author: Cathy S.

description: Looking for a non-chumpy bar in the FiDi? Last night after a movie at the Metreon, my friends and I wanted to grab a drink. We walked in and out of the W (too many old Sex in the City wannabees arriving in rented limos), and the Thirsty Bear had too many frat dudes. Distraught, we walked up New Montgomery ready to hit MUNI and call it a night, when we saw Austin Powers smoking outside the House of Shields. I'd always relegated it to a swanky lawyers hangout, but that was back in the day. Cool mod 60s music, great DJ, cozy booths. Only downside is the bartenders can be pretty slow, but they make an ok margarita. I'll definitely be back the next time I get caught after dark downtown.
author: Suzanne R.

description: Old fashioned pubs do it for me. Not always but when I need just a BAR then I prefer a pub any day. Lounges - too posh, Dive Bars - too dirty. Pubs are the Baby Bear of bars and this one is so just right I want to pinch its cheeks. Big plus are the statues on the wall and the the fact that they have New Belgium Skinny Dip on tap. I also think it maybe a fireman favorite because last time I was there it was a sausage fest of the FIREMAN kind. Literally I was the only woman there. It kind of made me think of bear bars in the Castro. But it wasn't, I saw too many dudes staring at my tits.
author: Alexis B.

description:
One of the last great San Francisco bars. A bit pickled, salty, always a different crowd. Especially now that Owl Tree & the old Redwood Room are gone and replaced by cheap replicas, it makes you appreciate what a real bar is. 

The thing I find funny about the recent negative reviews is that this crowd complained about the service sucking big time (having to wait 30 minutes for a drink), yet they were still able to spend over $200 there. Bars have bad nights; there are plenty more bars out there. If it's not working, there are plenty of other places ready for your money.

 Abuse your liver, not your spirit.

Anyway, sorry you guys had a bad bartender. This place has never been known for it's service, but don't judge the place on one bad server.
author: Floyd L.

description: What's to love about this bar? Well let's see...it was an old speakeasy, it has a really cool history (President Harding was rumored to have died here before being snuck through the underground tunnel connecting the bar to the Palace Hotel), there is cheap beer and it has awesome decor-especially the ceilings and cozy leather booths.
author: Sara W.

description: This seemed like a great place to visit based solely on yelp reviews, so I checked it out. I'm in SF for 2 weeks and don't know much about anything except for the fact that SF is amazing!  HoS was a great place to relax if u are looking for a low key place with a great atmos!  Good beer and seem like a locals spot, I could be wrong.  Reminded me of a good Philly bar.  I'll be back for more before I head back to the east coast.
author: Wes G.

description: Convenient location right off of market. Great for Happy Hours with co-workers after work, but strange distribution of space. I feel like they could have provided a LOT more seating if they planned the space better. Expect to stand if you don't get there right at 5!
author: Janie Y.

description: I love this place!! Now that I know a bartender threw down the gauntlet (so to speak) I love it even more!!  Hurray for standing up to douc*ebags who think they own the world! I love you bartender and will stop by and tip you soon.
author: Jason G.

description: A very comfortable spot to relax tucked away on a dreary, boring block. Something about the wooden interior calms me when I'm about to blow a gasket, or maybe it's just the booze. Speaking of the booze, the drinks are usually poured liberally, so the place is easy on the finances. Mmmm...booze.
author: Steven C.

description: I have been told that this place has awesome mojitos, but I was a little drunk when I here and just stuck to my usuals (i.e. Tanqueray and tonic followed by beer). When I got here, the place wasn't that full, but since I came with a whole crowd of Yelpers following an event, we quickly filled up the place. Despite the sudden influx of bar patrons, the bartenders were attentive, polite and fast. And they didn't fuck up my drink. As for the setting/ambiance...I can't really comment on that as I'm not entirely sure I fully took it in. I was more concerned with the (apparently) very in-depth (and "sober" at this point) conversations I was having with, um, well, everyone. Nevertheless, I will definitely return next time I'm in the area.
author: Veronica W.

description: I've always liked this place and I don't visit nearly often enough. The staff is always cool, the drinks are good and the crowd is usually a lot of fun. On occasion there are too may whiny, entitled Marina chicks but, until we build that wall at Gough St, that's bound to happen.
author: Joe H.

description: This place is a fine place to grab a pint.  It's a typical speak easy....I've never had any employees be rude or mean.  You generally get what you give...
author: Blake J.

description: A great place to have a private party upstairs while mingling with newbies downstairs.  Projections on the enormous wall behind the bar add an ecclectic mix. Great for bands, DJ's or just drinking with friends. The staff are friendly and creative with their concoctions.
author: Barbara B.

description: House of Shields is a gem in the dreary financial district. Super comfortable booths, well made drinks and a nice, laid back atmosphere even on weekend nights.
author: Maria D.

description: I used to work out next door to House of Shields at Crunch and let me tell you... it was hard not to pass by this place.  The music is cool when it's live, people are unpretentious, it's a low key after work drink out place, and the drinks are just the way I like it.  I could be here with friends or without.  What a lush....
author: Melissa M.

description: There was polka music and I didn't drive.  Somehow works out as a metaphor for my life.
author: Mike O.

description: Went there for the first time a few days ago, love the dark wood colors and the huge mirror behind the bar.  However, not that into the loud music and bar scene, maybe about 10 years too young. Typical, casual happy hour place.  The mint mojito was as it should be.
author: Cara J.

description: Out of Guinness Draft before 6.30pm on a weekday.  Totally disinterested and unfriendly bartender. Not worth my time. Not my cup of tea (or rather, my pint o' beer.)
author: nic t.

description: Great place to go if you like to drink inside a dark closet with loud music.  I just can't get into it.
author: Tempe M.

description: Freakin sweet. Dark as hell in an uplifting way. I'm almost night blind so this is a major plus. Hella eccentric men's room. The neon House of Shield's sign is priceless. Watch out for the shields, they might not have been the best idea for a building material.
author: Ryan B.

description: This place was recommended to me by my friend who said you have to go just to check out the innerds of the place.  First, the place is absolutely gorgeous inside.  We are talking a San Francisco classic with original finishing, original booths, orignal bar.  A full bar, a great selection of beers, great service, but some of the douchey-downtowners can surely get on your nerves...but most of all, a great place to grab a drink after work with friends.  I've only experienced the after work scene so not experienced with the late-night scene.  The crowd was mixed for sure, downtowners in suits, hipsters, and students (my type of place).
author: Boho H.

description: First timer here tonight.  Can't give it a 5 yet, but I'm definitely planning to go back and get a better feel of the place.  If you have a chance to get served by Kelly (not sure if it's Kelly or Kellie, but she's kick ass either way), do it... she's good at what she does, pours heavy, and is crazy fun as well.
author: Jay B.

description: First DYL!! Nonstop Vodka sodas, Nonstop talk for sex and boobies.Clean bathrooms What's not to love.
author: Douggers M.

description: ZAZZ!  I love this place!  But, I usually have to split by 9pm because  it is not unusual for some DJ to start playing some loud and obnoxious thump thump thump "music"!  Sometimes in the early evening a lazz or lounge act might play-much better for relaxing to when sipping one of their monsterously large martinis!
author: BRUCE S.

description: This place seems to be Jay H's downtown SF default "let's meet up for drinks but not go anywhere that we know anyone because we just wanna get trashed, yap it up and then go home with out any hubbub or pomp."  Gotta say, not a bad default.  Stupidly strong drinks (and by "stupidly" I mean "the way I behave after a few"), loud music, a nice, inconspicuous bike messenger crowd, and a cool interior.
author: vicarious c.

description:
i couldn't lock the bathroom door.  i was pretty liquored up but i knew i didn't want anyone walking in on me at such a vulnerable moment so i made someone stand outside and keep guard.

other than that, the place was great after the cartoon museum event.  comfortable booths, pretty people, beer, nice bartenders and some dancing, i believe, because someone made fun of me later.
author: Seong P.

description:
for a fidi bar, i'd say shields is a dive. this is a good thing cuz it keeps the corporates drones away. the bartenders are down and the drinks are stiff which spells trouble for a light weight like me. hey, lay off. i'm asian. at least, i don't turn red. anyhow, thank goodness i can just hop on bart and go home.

another plus. when 111 minna gets too crazy on qool wednesdays, i can always depend on shields for some sanity.
author: frisco j.

description: I like hanging out with friends here. The bartenders are nice and the drinks are good.  The booths are huge.  The downstairs is good for talking to your friends.  Upstairs is good for sweatin' to the oldies.  You'll realise how unique this place is when you check out the photos on the wall and see the size of the bathrooms.
author: Matt H.

description:
Oh the memories of the house of shields, walking, or should I say stumbling down into the deep basement which looked like a catacomb. Music basting away as wine on the cellar walls vibrate off and crashes on to the dirty cement floor. Oh them were the days.

As of late, I do not remember seeing the basement open but man was it great to party there! DJing down there was fun. That lil area used to pop off! It surely beat DJing up in the loft area.

As far as bars go, this is very typical but holds that historic feel to it. I for one love getting blasted here. I should return though, it has been quite some time!
author: Jay D.

description: Oh why are you so close to work, and so easy to get to?  I like this place, it's been open since 1901 or something.. and the decor is cool.  You really can't go wrong when they have 2 dollar PBR's everyday.  Oh great story, my coworkers and I were there from 6 to about 9 and at 9 it got so packed and noticed that everyone had name tags on.. we asked what was going on, and apparently it was Singles night!  So if you're single you could get a free shot of Jamison or Fernet.. coolest bar ever, but the story i told was way cooler.  It's late i'm going to bed
author: Joanne W.

description: the actual bar aspect of it is kinda cute . I like the architecture and all that noise. The playing area for bands is stupidly small,and gets furnace like .Seeing that I am going to hell one day maybe I should just get used to it,but until I go to my fiery resting place I'm cool off concentration camp type conditions. Fuck it!
author: Lauren V.

description: It looks so cool from the outside that I was expecting to be amazed a little too much. But despite the lack  of shields and armored knights that I so oddly expected, I found this to be a pretty good place for folks to meet and hang out. The beers were a dollar more expensive than I like and the bartender was a little surly to one of my companions, and if I could I'd probably give them 3.5 stars rather than 4.
author: Ian M.

description: This is probably where you will find me most Thursday and Fridays after work.  $2 Pabst aren't very tasty, but they are cheep.
author: Justin J.

description: This is a good place to get a drink after work. Bartender is always nice and prices are good. Bottle beers could be colder, but the cocktails are always stiff! Interesting crowd.
author: Lisa A.

description: The non-dive dive, House of Shields seems to have earned its reputation as the go-to after-work place with a generally good crowd and drinks cheaper and better than anywhere else in SoMa. Equal parts business folk, afternoon drunks and ambient, blind date meeting place. Goth interior makes it look like an old, stately hotel. It's not my choice venue for live music - located upstairs on select nights - but it was my favorite when I worked down the street. Easy access to Montgomery BART if you leave before closing time.
author: Tara R.

description: Dimly lit with original Victorian wood paneled splendor, this place features some truly cool musicians and DJ's. The girls behind the bar pour with a heavy hand, just don't go asking for anything fancy.. It's also good to know, If Minna on Wednesday nights gets too much, you can always make your escape here.
author: Stellah D.

description: I stopped by this bar after the Chinese New Year parade not too long ago.  The crowd was diverse and just generally chill.  There weren't any loud talkers or overbearing groups of people.  It seemed like a nice place to grab a drink or two if you are in the FiDi.  It's definitely on my list of places to try to bring co-workers at the end of the day.
author: Luis M.

description: House of Shields is a very relaxing, homey sort of bar with lots of small booths and a convenient location near Market. Drinks are reasonably priced, not cheap but not too expensive, and the bartenders are friendly. Supposedly the place gets super packed around happy hour, but there's plenty of seating later on. House of Shields is definitely a great place to grab a beer if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Will A.

description: Good happy hour spot, crowd was good, service was horrible.  Stock beers and plenty of copper mugs to go around.  I probably won't hurry back.
author: Chase B.

description: Not entirely a dive bar - due to the clientèle.  Many people finishing up a day at work, still somewhat suited up, with a drink or two, but still a terrific place.  Very comfortable, nice and dark - and they have Boddingtons on tap!  I'm easily pleased, apparently, for when the next shift started, and the bartender plugged his ipod in...the Pixies began to play, and I knew I had a new place to call a home away from home.  That's all it took, laid back spot, good drinks, good music, and done.
author: Claire F.

description: I found nothing too extraordinary at Shields, except for the entertainment balcony. That was clutch when we bombarded the place with 15-20 thirsty Yelpers. Beer selection was slightly above average for an SF dive bar, not as good as my current crush, Inner Mission Beer Parlor. Can't comment on service since my colleague was kind enough to order for me.
author: Susan L.

description: Walk past the stodgy facade and into a great after-work spot. It's a combination of Old San Francisco meets the 21st century. Antique wood paneling, a hip and eclectic crowd, and good music give this place a unique vibe.
author: Shannon L.

description: Its become my favorite place to meet the girls after work. How did I NOT know this was here for so many years. I love the central location to downtown . . . easy for quick happy hours. The crowd is a great mix of everyone in the city  . . . some FIDI folks, mission-y types, very unpretentious and very cool. The drinks are cheap but GOOD and I love the big mirrors and goth-y ish feel. Kinda edgy, nice cross-section of folks. You can find me sunk into one of the cool booths with my friends a few times (or more) a month ;)
author: Elizabeth S.

description: I have issues with my purse, I can never find what I need from it when I need it. I went to House of Shields after work just to go along, but was not in the mood to drink. My two friends ordered and I said I didn't want anything. Then she asked for IDs and looked straight at me, well my friends beat me to it and had theirs out quick, when I wasn't fast enough she looked at me and yelled "Even if you aren't drinking I need to see your ID, you have to be 21 to be in a bar we don't serve food here!" I wasn't defying her! I was trying! I was a bartender before, and I don't think I would ever be that rude to someone who just arrived, doesn't leave a very good impression. There were a lot of bikers...( bike messengers not like...bikers bikers) and a pretty relaxed atmosphere. Just wish I didn't have such a negative first impression!
author: Whitney F.

description: Needless to say I will not be going back to this bar.  Its down the street from my house and a friend was having a party there which was the only reason I stopped by.  The door guy was an asshole by makeing smartass comments about mine and my friends ID's and then the bartender was rude and totally acting like it was a hassel to pour 2 beers.  Beers I might add not like we were makeing him make a long island.
author: Mother L.

description: If you want a bar that is truly a classic with great atmosphere and finely made classic cocktails then this is your spot.  Don't be in a hurry and be grateful that they handcraft an amazing drink.
author: Robin G.

description: Nice little bar.  I had my first drink being 21 there.  It was a shot of some concotion made by the lovely bartender.  I had to leave after i took it though since i was on break and i had to take a miderm.  Nice chill spot, i always hear some good music coming out of there.  Also nice crowd of all types of groups.  I would suggest anyone who hasn't been in yet should at least have a drink.
author: Jonathan F.

description: Starting on a positive note, great ole time bar in great location with lots of young "hip" after-work non-yuppie crowd, so that's good.  But, as a serious Martini aficionado, being served my drink of choice in a champagne glass by a dour bartender proffering a shitty and small libation is not my idea of fun.  Zero stars on the Martini scale. Go elsewhere for a good Martini, if that's your poison.  Oh yeh, way too loud for any real conversation.
author: Stephen S.

description: I must've been there on an off night... Nothing really stood out to me aside from the wobbly table and booth with a broken bench seat.  I'll have to try again I guess!
author: Kyla B.

description:
i love drinking at this establishment.  cause i can get trashed and no one gives a shit.  cause they're all trashed too.
